search_result.title: Delaware schools struggle with proposed cuts
search_result.text:
Jessica Bies, and Matthew Albright

The News Journal

Educators and parents are up in arms over $37 million in budget cuts to public schools proposed by Gov. John Carney and vow a fight in the General Assembly to stop them.

"At some point in time, we have to look at our future and stop robbing Peter to pay Paul," said Jeff Day, who is running for a spot on the Christina school board and has children in the Appoquinimink district.

Carney has said he would rather not be making any cuts but said "shared sacrifice" is necessary in the face of the state's nearly $400 million budget deficit.

"These are extremely modest cuts in the scheme of things, and other cabinet agencies are being cut a lot more," Carney said. "All we're asking is that our school boards do a little more to run a little more efficiently."

STORY: Standoff ends in Middletown; suspect in Delaware trooper death killed

STORY: Fear spreads through Middletown-area neighborhood

The cuts are only 1.5 percent of the state's $1.37 billion public school budget, the governor noted.

About $15 million of the cuts will come straight from school districts' operational funds, money that generally isn't used to pay teachers but covers training, technology and other administrative costs.

An additional $22 million will come from something called the "education sustainment fund," which is used for a much wider range of services like math and reading specialists, after-school programming and paying staff salaries over the summer, before tax receipts come in.

Carney's plan would allow districts to make up the $22 million cut by giving school districts a one-time shot at raising property taxes – without asking their voters in a referendum. It would need the approval of the General Assembly.

That would leave only a $15 million cut spread over the entire system, the governor reasons.

But school board members say the decision to raise that so-called "match tax" would put them in the painful position of losing money or outraging taxpayers at a time when many school boards already are struggling to pass referendums.

School board members also say the property tax increases would unfairly burden taxpayers in property-poor districts.

“It’s foolish, I think, and a fool’s errand when the state is facing a big deficit like it is, to argue the state shouldn't cut education," Appoquinimink school board President Richard Forsten said. “Times are tough and everyone needs to tighten their belts … but if we’re going to do it, it needs to be fair.”

A tight timeline

The General Assembly has until June 30 to debate the state budget, and school districts have only until July 13 to get tax warrants to their local counties, giving them little time to ponder a final decision on the match tax.

The dilemma for superintendents and principals is that state law mandates any teacher laid off must be notified no later than May 15.

STORY: Carney proposes tax hikes, spending cuts in state budget

STORY: Delaware's budget hole deepens by $35.6 million

Districts will need to plan for cuts they aren't even sure are coming. That means they might be sending pink slips to employees they might not need to fire.

Conversely, the cuts may deepen and they may have dip into their reserves or get rid of school programs.

Rep. Melanie George Smith, D-Bear and chair of the budget-writing Joint Finance Committee, acknowledges the timing is tough for districts. But she said it's too early in the General Assembly to give a final ruling.

Lawmakers still have to settle the thorny question of how much to cut and how much to raise revenue. Carney has proposed an equal balance of tax increases and spending cuts, but lawmakers don't have to follow that rule.

While there's little appetite among lawmakers to balance the budget with nearly $400 million in tax increases — thus avoiding cuts entirely — they could lean a little heavier on taxes than Carney did. They could expand Carney's proposed increases to the income tax, corporate franchise tax and tobacco tax. Or they could impose other hikes, like expanding the lodging tax or adding to the alcohol tax.

That could mean the proposed cuts to education would vanish or diminish.

This revenue issue is perhaps the biggest question looming over the current General Assembly. And Smith said her committee won't know how to handle education cuts until that question is answered.

"We on JFC can't say what we're going to do until our 62 colleagues decide what kind of revenue we have to work with," Smith said.

She said it's also possible her committee will find other, less painful places to cut education spending.

"The question isn't how much we're cutting; the question is what we're cutting," she said. "We can find places to cut spending that don't affect direct instruction."

But "there really are no easy answers here," George cautioned.

If state government were to avoid education cuts, it would have to make deeply painful cuts elsewhere. Education makes up about one-third of the budget.

The only other part of government that is anywhere near that size is health and social services, on which the state spends about $1.1 billion.

Story continues below graph.

Schools have been taking up a greater share of the state budget each year because state officials are required by law to increase funding as the number of students in public schools grows. As a result, the number of education employees in Delaware has grown significantly even as the number of other government workers has declined.

STORY: Gov. John Carney: Fix budget, update Coastal Zone Act

In 2009, there were 16,877 school district employees — as of this February, that number had grown to 19,422. During the same period, the number of other state government employees shrank from 14,103 to 13,338.

While Carney has insisted he does not intend for schools to cut staff, salaries are the biggest part of every district's budget. Which has several of them looking at layoffs.

To tax or not to tax?

The cuts are worse if school boards don't impose the referendum-less "match tax."

For instance, Christina School District is estimating total losses of about $5.86 million — $3.9 million of which it could potentially recover via the match tax.

That means raising taxes 7.3 cents per $100 of assessed property value. For example, a home in Windy Hills, Newark, recently sold for $224,000 has an assessed property value of $63,700 and would face a potential annual property tax increase of $46.50, according to district records.

In comparison, Christina’s last referendum, held in 2016, raised taxes by 30 cents, an increase of about $191 per year on a similarly valued home.

Even if the district ultimately decides to raise taxes without voter approval, it still would have to make about $2 million in cuts, according to Christina Financial Manager Bob Silber. Due to timing considerations, it's also making plans for the full $5.9 million.

Causalities could include the district's Montessori Program, which has an enrollment of about 60 students and was recently re-committed to by the school board. Another option is to discontinue elementary instrumental music and elementary and secondary string music classes.

The cuts seem large, but for some school districts, reductions are compounded by the fact they already planned on making large ones next year.

Take Indian River, which days before Carney released his budget had outlined $1.72 million in reductions.

Though it recently passed a $7.35 million referendum, the district has been struggling financially and planned on reducing the amount of paid coaching staff for athletics and some salary reductions, including eliminating non-athletic extra pay for extra responsibilities.

The plan was to streamline programs, not eliminate them. But now, with Indian River facing a total of about $3.4 million in cuts, the scope of that original budget reduction plan could change. Passing the “match tax” would raise taxes about 12.5 cents per $100 of assessed property value, Superintendent Mark Steele told residents during a recent "town hall" held on Facebook Live.

STORY: Colonial takes another shot at referendum, warns of cuts

STORY: Indian River School District faces $3.4M in cuts

For Colonial, which is holding a referendum June 6, there's even more on the line.

The district's last referendum, in February, was voted down, which means the district was already considering cuts.

Should the June referendum also be defeated, Colonial is preparing to implement over $4 million in reductions for the 2017-2018 school year, including 120 layoffs. The budget cuts add roughly another 50 layoffs, bring the total to 170.

Those estimates are based on the total cuts the district could see in the budget — about $3 million — and does not include the match tax.

"The idea of the referendum is really to make us whole," Colonial Superintendent Dusty Blakey said. "To keep us at our operating level currently."

Shared sacrifice

Other school districts, like Appoquinimink, are approaching the education cuts a little differently. The district is considering reducing transportation costs, reducing its budget for substitute custodians and eliminating up to 17 teachers, among other things.

Forsten, the school board's president, seems to realize cuts, if not inevitable, are likely. He's trying to prepare for them.

He and the district's financial director, Charles Longfellow, are working to ensure that even if the district has to raise taxes, it's doing so in a way that's fair to local residents.

Because the way Carney has proposed doing it, that's not fair, Forsten said.

He said because the cuts aren't based on districts' property tax bases, some Delaware homeowners will have to pay only a little bit more in taxes each year, while homeowners in districts like Appoquinimink would shell out a pretty significant chunk of change.

Forsten used Brandywine, which like Appoquinimink is facing about $3 million in total cuts, as a comparison.

If Brandywine and Appoquinimink both had to cover the total $3 million, he said, the taxes in Appoquinimink would be higher.

In Brandywine, a home valued at $63,700 would face annual property tax increase of about $56. In Appoquinimink, where rates needed to be raised more because there's less taxable property, taxes will go up by about $95.

Forsten thinks the formula for calculating the cuts needs to be changed, so residents all pay roughly the same.

At a board workshop Wednesday night, not all agreed.

Christina's Day says instead of suggesting changes to how the cuts are made, school boards throughout the state should be rallying against any cuts at all.

"Don't roll over, acquiesce and say, 'Yes, Dover, if you give us the authority to match tax, we'll use it,'" Day said. "Otherwise, they'll just keep doing this."

He also thinks resources given to school districts should be the same across the state, and that Appoquinimink should be fighting to eliminate the cuts altogether instead of looking out for its "best interests" and making sure it doesn't have to pay significantly more in taxes than Brandywine or Christina.

"I think we should be fighting so that all kids in the state are not hurt by this budget," Day said.

Contact Jessica Bies at (302) 324-2881 or jbies@delawareonline.com. Follow her on Twitter @jessicajbies. Contact Matthew Albright at malbright@delawareonline.com, (302) 324-2428 or on Twitter @TNJ_malbright.

search_result.title: At what cost? School referendums splinter communities
search_result.text:
Matthew Albright, and Saranac Hale Spencer

The News Journal

Voters are set to consider three referendums statewide that would would raise almost $500 million.

School district officials say they're forced to ask for money because of the state's complex funding system.

The regular referendums have sparked tension among voters who are asked to fund education.

Spring is the time of year when education turns into politics, when school districts give residents a choice: Vote to raise property taxes or face teacher and program cuts.

Nobody — not seniors, not parents, not even school officials who say the money is desperately needed — like asking for a tax hike.

School supporters and parents bemoan the fact that educators and parents are forced to campaign for referendums, rather than focus on teaching children.

What's frequently misunderstood by citizens is that referendums are often intended only to keep the status quo, supporters say. But Delaware's complex school funding system has made it difficult to convince voters the increases are necessary to cover growing student enrollment and maintenance costs.

"There's so much time and energy that has to be poured into it, it's just hundreds and hundreds of man hours," said Eve Buckley, a Christina School District parent who is one of the volunteer leaders in an effort to pass that district's referendum on Wednesday. "And it's time you're using just in hopes of staying where we are, maybe getting a little better, not providing some big new idea. The process is a real drain."

Brandywine and Cape Henlopen also are seeking voters' approval that day. The three referendums combined would raise almost $500 million.

The success of those votes comes down to whether district officials can coax enough parents with children in public schools to go to the polls. They must outnumber those who don't feel they have a stake in the schools or who feel districts should do more to prove they deserve a tax increase.

"If I go to my boss and haven't done what I'm supposed to ... I don't ask for a raise," said Susan Welsh, who wants to see Christina begin to improve student test scores and find efficiencies before she votes in favor. "I love my child enough to vote 'no' and hold them [the district] accountable to raising the ranking before I give them a raise."

District supporters say referendums aren't a luxury. They are a necessity.

Money that pays for schools is a mix of state, federal and local funds. While the state's portion grows as districts enroll more students, the local portion comes from property taxes that don't increase to match growing costs.

If districts don't get the money to cover those costs, the results can be demoralizing, Buckley says.

"You want to think you're part of a community that is at least reasonably supportive of public education, and then something like what happened last year takes place," she said. "And then you start to worry about this negative feedback loop, where people think the district isn't worthy, so then we have to cut budgets. And that means the schools suffer, and the perception only gets reinforced."

Acting Christina Superintendent Bob Andrzejewski says its dangerous to leave districts without a steady, reliable base of funding.

"There are no reruns when it comes to education," he said. "If a student misses out on important educational services because there's no money, you can't go back and make that up later."

Christina is seeking about $16 million, which would amount to roughly $192 a year more in taxes for the average homeowner, according to the district. That money would be used to plug some of the holes left after the district slashed $9 million from its budget last year and would also add some new programs.

Brandywine is asking taxpayers for money to cover operating expenses, for work on school buildings and to put synthetic turf on its athletic fields. It estimates that an average home-owner would pay an extra $243 per year for the next three years and $206 per year after the $1.7 million turf project will be done. The district needs $19.3 million for the building projects and $9.5 million for operating expenses.

The referendum in Cape Henlopen is a little different – it is asking voters for money that would be used strictly for building two elementary schools and doing work on two others, which is the last phase in a 20-year, long-term plan that the district committed itself to in 1999. The total cost for the project is $154.5 million, but local taxpayers are being asked to shoulder $48.4 million of it.

Swaying the public

The base of the bloc that typically votes against referendums is believed to be older residents who don't have children, don't directly benefit from the tax increases and are often on fixed incomes.

Older residents vote more than younger residents. And low-income families are less likely to vote than more affluent families, who may not send their children to traditional public schools, Buckley said.

That stacks referendums against the districts.

"It's a huge challenge, no question," Buckley said.

In Christina's first referendum last year, when voters slapped down a tax increase by an almost three-to-one margin, turnout in more affluent suburban areas dwarfed turnout in poorer urban areas.

STORY: Robocalls used in Christina schools referendum

STORY: Wilmington redistricting plan advances on shaky ground



In five polling places in Wilmington, there were a total of 258 votes. At a single suburban polling place – McVey Elementary, just off the University of Delaware campus – more than 556 people voted.

The vote failed 2,119 – 6,076.

When Christina took a second shot with a smaller referendum last year, the district made more energetic efforts to get the word out to voters, and turnout evened out somewhat. The referendum failed again, but this time by less than 900 votes out of more than 11,000.

"The support's there," said Brian Stephan, a parent with two children in Christina and co-chair of the district's referendum steering committee. "It's just tapping into it and letting them know where to be and what you're voting for."

Part of the problem, supporters say, is that the state's school finance system is so complicated.

Stephan points out that school referendums are the only time residents get to choose whether to tax themselves. For other taxes, elected representatives choose when to raise rates; citizens vote those representatives out if they don't like their choices.

"It's the one chance that people get, so they tend to vent some of their frustrations," he said. "It doesn't just become about school taxes, it's all taxes. And that makes it hard for us."

Referendum opponents do frequently bring up other tax proposals.

"The governor wants to put more money in for the gas tax, he wants to give more money to the casinos," said Marie Lulfs, a 76-year-old Christina resident. "Everybody wants more money, and where are they getting it from? The taxpayer."

What's at stake

Nobody knows the impacts of a failed referendum quite like Christina parents and teachers.

After voters twice rejected tax increases last year, the district made more than $9 million in cuts, laying off 78 teachers and 14 aides.

Stephan's daughter's first-grade class has 37 students, far more than last year.

"That has been an extreme challenge for her teacher and for her," Stephan said. "You can just tell when she comes home from school."

Supporters like Stephan say it is hard to make voters understand that operating referendums don't necessarily mean a district is seeking new goodies. In some cases, like Christina's, they are simply asking for enough money to preserve the level of services.

About 55 percent of Christina's budget comes from state funding, while 38 percent comes from local property taxes (the rest comes from federal sources).

The state's share of school taxes grows as the district adds students, but the property tax revenue doesn't always do so.

Unlike many states, school taxes don't automatically adjust for inflation. So when costs of things like fuel and electricity go up, the money a district gets from property taxes buys less and less.

If more of the budget goes toward overhead, there is less available for educational programs.

That argument hasn't convinced some referendum opponents.

"They got $20 million five years ago – it didn't do anything," said Welsh. "So what's this $16 million going to do? There's no proof in the pudding."

A better system?

Michael Griffith, who studies school finance issues at the Colorado-based Education Commission of the States, said local school funding mechanisms vary widely from state to state. When it comes to picking the best method, he said figuring out "the one true religion is probably easier than this."

Most states require voter approval for school tax increases, he said. But many allow districts the choice to occasionally raise taxes by a small amount, usually tied to an inflation rate, without going to voters.

"If you believe in public education, as we do, the quality of our childrens' educational experience should not depend on a vote," Andrzejewski said. "There are very few states left in the country that require referendums for operating expenses."

Andrzejewski, who was previously Red Clay superintendent and has worked on several referendums, argues the state should move to a similar system. Delaware's vo-tech school districts, he points out, are given the ability to raise taxes up to a certain cap before getting the General Assembly's approval.

"There is a politically accepted, viable model that Delaware already has," Andrzejewski said. "School board members are elected officials just as the General Assembly is. They should be trusted to make a prudent financial decision on behalf of the community."

For taxpayers, Andrzejewski said a system like this would allow districts to raise taxes gradually over time, instead of periodically hitting them with one big increase all at once. Inflation rates are typically under two percent; by contrast, Christina is looking for a 21 percent increase in its tax rate.

There are two big caveats, Andrzejewski says.

First, school board members should be required to get financial training and should be penalized if they don't.

And second, districts should still be required to go to referendum for major new programs or building campaigns.

Are schools 'electioneering?

Another problem is Delaware districts are sometimes accused of employing underhanded tactics to get the votes they need.

The same day Christina's first referendum failed in 2015, Red Clay passed one. Almost immediately, some residents cried foul.

Many Red Clay schools held parent engagement events on the night of the vote in their buildings, which serve as polling places. Several older voters said those events crowded parking lots, denying them parking spaces that were close enough for them to make it in to vote. It also boosted turnout among parents.

An ACLU of Delaware lawsuit over those claims is still making its way through the courts. Red Clay maintains that it took sufficient steps to provide enough parking and argued it frequently holds events at schools to keep parents engaged in their kids' education.

STORY: Christina School District takes third try at referendum

STORY: UD to make SAT optional

State Sen. Karen Peterson, D-Stanton, received numerous complaints from constituents.

"Last year's Red Clay district referendum was the poster child for what's wrong with the whole system," Peterson said. "There was so much electioneering that went on inside the polling places that it was just an absolute disgrace."

Peterson says this isn't the first time a district has been accused of electioneering, referencing a so-called "Pizza-gate" incident a few years ago in which Smyrna schools threw pizza parties at schools on referendum night.

"I couldn't stand inside a polling place and hand out pizza if you voted for me," Peterson said.

Peterson has proposed a bill that would change how districts go out to referendums.

First, schools could only seek one referendum a year, at the same time as school board elections. That would save the state Department of Elections money and force districts to make one pitch for what they really need.

The fact that districts often come right back with referendum requests if a previous one fails upsets many opponents.

"If you say 'no' once, I mean 'no," Lulfs said. "You don't have to keep shoving it down my throat."

Peterson's bill would also have referendums conducted via mail. That would make more voters aware of the issues, she said, and prevent the inherent problems in having polling places that directly benefit from the results of a vote.

"We don't have to worry about all this going on at the schools," she said.

While Peterson argues these changes would make the system fairer, she agrees with some school supporters who say broader change is a good idea.

"These districts can get in a really bad place, because this is money they really do need," she said. "But you're asking people to vote for a tax on themselves. Something has to change."

Contact Matthew Albright at malbright@delawareonline.com, (302) 324-2428, or on Twitter @TNJ_malbright. Contact Saranac Hale Spencer at (302) 324-2909, sspencer@delawareonline.com or on Twitter @SSpencerTNJ.

search_result.title: Indian River audit: Money spent on jewelry, events
search_result.text:
Jerry Smith

The News Journal

An audit of the Indian River School District’s finances and of its chief financial officer found the district lacked formal policies and procedures for any of its financial processes the past five years.

The findings were released by the state’s Office of Auditor of Accounts during a Thursday briefing in Dover, and the final report was released simultaneously to the public via the office’s website.

“I am sending a message to Indian River and everyone in the state to be careful about how you manage taxpayer money,” said Delaware’s Auditor of Accounts R. Thomas Wagner Jr. “At the end of the day, if you are the board, it is your responsibility.”

Among the processes questioned were unauthorized use of the board president’s signature stamp to approve transactions, a payroll process controlled entirely by the CFO “that severely lacked documentation and review” and an abundance of in-state meals that did not appear to meet the criteria provided by the state’s Budget and Accounting Manual.

Several employees stated they were forced to share log-in credentials into the state’s accounting system, which is a violation of the state’s computer usage security policies, according to the audit.

Several types of purchases were deemed inappropriate or questionable based on a lack of supporting documentation. Those included a Teacher of the Year ceremony held at Baywood Greens for approximately $7,000, Alex and Ani bracelets totaling $352 for certain district office staff and a Tiffany & Co. bracelet for $380 as a recognition gift to Superintendent Susan Bunting.

In December 2015, the auditor's office received complaints on its fraud hotline about alleged financial misconduct by district CFO Patrick Miller. The audit of the district’s $50 million annual budget began shortly after Miller was placed on leave April 24. Miller later submitted his resignation, effective June 30.

STORY: DuPont to end pension contribution for active employees

STORY: Student breathalyzers anger Smyrna parents

When the audit was launched for the time period of July 1, 2011 to June 30, 2016, district officials did not reveal what led to Miller’s involuntary leave or the state of the audit itself. On Thursday, district grant writer David Maull said comment would be reserved until a Friday morning briefing at the district office in Selbyville.

Wagner said Bunting and the Indian River School District were very cooperative during the investigation.

“They accepted the findings and want to fix the problems in the district,” Wagner said. “Dr. Bunting has asked for our help. I think in a year and a half from now, Indian River will be running smooth and fine. She seriously wants to fix the problems.”

The findings come less than a week before Indian River School District's referendum seeking additional local funding for school security programs, technology, textbooks, student organizations and measures related to enrollment growth.

Wagner waved off any suggestion the timing was political, saying people are going to think what they want.

“The two don’t equate to each other. We just try to put the facts out there in a timely manner,” he said.

In the Nov. 22 referendum, the district is seeking a tax increase of 49 cents per $100 of assessed property value to raise $7.35 million in operating funds.

The district has experienced budget issues because of enrollment growth, including an increase of 296 students from last year, giving the district 10,467 students. Enrollment has grown an average of 3 to 4 percent every year since 2010.

The Indian River School District was formed in 1969 through the consolidation of several smaller districts and now is the fifth-largest district in the state. There are eight elementary schools, three middle schools, two high schools and three special service schools over 365-square miles.

Further findings from the audit revealed that Miller made a payment of $20,343 to the Indian River Volunteer Fire company, and another for $32,500 to the Boys & Girls Club of Oak Orchard/Riverdale. The CFO served as board president for both organizations.

The audit also found “the District’s processes centralized around the CFO’s review and approval of financial transactions due to the District’s complete trust in him. This blind trust resulted in the CFO’s work not being reviewed and the complete absence of policies and procedures, amongst other issues discussed in this report. Because of these deficient internal controls, an environment in which employees were intimidated and afraid to speak up or report concerns was created.”

Miller also had been audited in his previous job as business manager of the Brandywine School District. He faced criminal charges as the result of that audit and resolved his legal troubles by entering a no contest plea before Superior Court Judge Carl Goldstein.

Settlement of those charges came after he began his new position with the Indian River School District.

Reach Jerry Smith at jsmith17@delawareonline.com. Follow him on Twitter at @JerrySmithTNJ.

EDITOR’S NOTE: Previous versions of this story had an incorrect former job for Patrick Miller. Before coming to IR, he was business manager in the Brandywine School district.

search_result.title: The Daily Scroll: May 16-17
search_result.text:
Jessica Bies

The News Journal

Consultant: $300M required to support port growth

The state-owned Port of Wilmington will need up to $300 million for new warehouses, cranes and land to keep up with growing demands over the next two decades, according to a master plan that lays out options for future growth released Monday.

The blueprint calls for more investments from private sources and is the next step in a long-running discussion about how to grow the critical shipping economy.



"All the numbers you saw today are big. They are all a challenge to a state that has significant budget constraints. So if we are going to expand in a significant way, we are going to have to partner with other investors," said Delaware Secretary of State Jeffrey Bullock, chairman of Diamond State Port Corp., the public-private board that oversees the sprawling complex.

Read more here.

16-year-old boy shot in Wilmington

Wilmington police responded to the 1000 block of N. Lombard St. on Monday night to find a 16-year-old boy had been shot in his right leg.

The victim was treated at the scene by New Castle County Paramedics and transported to the Nemours/A.I duPont Hospital for Children Emergency Room in good condition.

The investigation is ongoing.

Anyone with information in reference to this shooting, which happened at about 7:58 p.m., is asked to call Detective Pete Leccia at (302) 576-3647.

Residents nearby stood and watched the scene.

“When you hear one shot and somebody got hurt, that’s personal. That hits close to home. I’m ready to leave here,” said nearby resident Zillah Edwards, who was home planning her wedding when she heard the shot.

More here.

Delaware Memorial Bridge lost $204,544 after lane closures

Last month's traffic nightmare produced by three days of Delaware Memorial Bridge lane closures resulted in $204,544 in lost toll revenue, the agency that operates the span said Tuesday.

Three lanes on the 3,650-foot Delaware-bound crossing were closed April 19-21 after inspectors found 2.25- and 2.5-inch support cables connecting the roadway to the bridge needed to be fixed immediately. Only the far right lane was left open.

Motorists endured delays of 2½ to 4 hours in backups stretching up to five miles on Interstate 295.

The Delaware River and Bay Authority said 93,476 vehicles did cross during those days, but that's a 27 percent decrease from the prior year.

"If you want continued repair and maintenance on the bridge, you got to do what you got to do, and there's just inconvenience," said DRBA Commissioner Richard W. Downes on Tuesday.

Read more here.

Brandywine district's second referendum is Tuesday

The Brandywine School District is putting up a referendum on Tuesday asking residents to approve a tax increase of 28 cents per $100 of assessed property value to support its regular operating budget, plus approve funding for a special building project.

It will be the second time this year that the district has gone to voters with those proposals – the last time they were paired with a plan to install synthetic turf fields at some schools. All three of those proposals – for a tax increase to support the regular operating budget, for funding to cover the cost of the building project and for money to install synthetic turf fields – were bundled together in a single vote that was rejected by a very slim margin in March. The district decided last month to present the same plan again, without the synthetic turf project.

Districts can go out for a referendum twice in a one-year span, according to Anthony Albence, director of the New Castle County Office of the Board of Elections. Last year, the Christina School District was in a situation similar to the one Brandywine is in now – its first bid for an increase in taxes to support its operating budget failed, so it went out for a second one. That one failed, too. But, this past March, Christina got its 21-percent tax increase passed.

Brandywine has a $174 million budget for the next school year, but will have to slash $8 million if the referendum doesn't pass, according to Superintendent Mark Holodic

Read more here.

Del. sues massage parlors owner in prostitution sting

Delaware prosecutors are suing the owner of four massage parlors who was caught in an undercover police investigation into prostitution in 2014.

The lawsuit filed Friday seeks $700,000 in civil penalties from Smyrna resident Da Zhong Wang, 52, for violating state racketeering laws. It also seeks to stop Wang from owning and operating massage parlors in Delaware.

Wang, a Chinese citizen living in the U.S. on a work permit, previously owned Relaxed Spa in Rehoboth, Massage Center in Middletown, Wang's House of Acupressure in Smyrna and Da Wang's Bodyworks in Dover, the lawsuit said.

In November 2013, an undercover Delaware State Police trooper visited the Middletown location. The masseuse offered the officer a sex act during the massage, the lawsuit said.

Read more here.

Wilmington mayor, council president release budget compromise

Wilmington Mayor Dennis P. Williams and City Council President Theo Gregory announced Monday they've agreed on staffing reductions, funding inefficiency studies for two departments and money for the city's land bank.

The proposal will be vetted by the Finance Committee on Monday at 5 p.m. and is scheduled to be voted on Thursday by the full 13-member City Council.

According to a news release, the $154 million budget now is $613,000 lower than the budget proposed by Williams in March.

Gregory said in a statement: “We were able to eliminate some positions which will produce longer term savings, identify new funding for the land bank and other neighborhood-based housing projects and we found money so we can finally move forward with departmental management studies to help us become a more efficient government. Budgets are all about compromising and that’s what we’ve done in this case.”

Read more here.

Bill would guarantee public defenders for juveniles

Top Delaware lawmakers want to guarantee juveniles have access to a public defender, regardless of family income or the level of their alleged crime.

The state Office of Defense Services already offers free legal representation to young people facing charges, even though it's not required by state law. House Bill 382 seeks to set the policy in stone so that future budget cuts or changes in leadership don't change that.

Speaker of the House Pete Schwartzkopf, D-Rehoboth Beach, who sponsored the legislation, said in a statement, "We can’t rely on current practice as a guarantee for the future."

The change, if approved, would mean the courts and Public Defender's Office will be required to continue the practice.

"This legislation takes the small but important step of codifying an existing practice so going forward there is no question that minors being charged with a crime in our state have the same rights to public defenders as adults," said Senate President Pro Tempore Patricia Blevins, D-Elsmere, lead sponsor of the bill in the Senate.

Read more here.

Lenore Matusiewicz dies while serving life sentence

After years of high-profile schemes and court battles over her grandchildren, Lenore Matusiewicz has quietly died in a Texas prison.

Matusiewicz, whose late husband fatally shot their former daughter-in-law at the New Castle County Courthouse in 2013, was sentenced to life in prison on harassing and stalking charges just three months ago.

The 71-year-old died at the Federal Medical Center Carswell in Fort Worth, Texas, on May 6, according to a Federal Bureau of Prisons online inmate locator. A cause was not immediately available.

Lenore Matusiewicz's brother, Tom Kula, told the Associated Press he was notified of her death May 7.

She had been in ailing health since being sentenced in February by a federal judge who took the unusual step of conducting the hearing at her bedside at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia.

Thomas Matusiewicz opened fire on their ex-daughter-in-law Christine Belford and her friend “Beth” Mulford as they walked into the New Castle County Courthouse lobby for a child support hearing with David Matusiewicz on Feb. 11, 2013. David is Lenore and Thomas's son and Belford's ex-husband.

The federal government accused Lenore Matusiewicz and her children – Newark optometrist David and nurse Amy Gonzalez – of waging a campaign to harass, torment, stalk and spy on Belford and the couple's three daughters in the three years leading up to Belford's death.

Read more here.

Police identify construction worker on I-95

Police have identified the man fatally struck Monday night on I-95 northbound in the Wilmington area as 36-year-old Aleksandr Y. Mitishov, according to Delaware State Police.

A police investigation determined that the crash occurred around 7:34 p.m. when Mitishov exited the driver's seat of a 2014 Ford F-350 parked on the right-hand shoulder of I-95 on the Brandywine River Bridge, south of U.S. 202, police said.

Mitishov, who was employed by Enterprise Flasher Company of Wilmington, was preparing to set up construction warning signage and was wearing a reflective vest when he stepped out into the right hand lane of travel, police said.

He was then struck by the right side front of a 1998 Nissan Quest, driven by Victor M. Sitiriche, 35, of Wilmington, police said.

Read more here.

The Power of Food TV on Delaware chefs' careers

Can an appearance on a national TV culinary show change your life?

Yes, it can.

Just ask Newark pastry chef Dana Herbert, winner of “Cake Boss: Next Great Baker,” a TLC pastry competition program hosted by star baker Buddy Valastro.

Herbert, who took home the title in December 2010, says the series gave him a national platform that showcased his baking and decorating skills. It also helped the University of Delaware graduate expand his thriving custom cake making business and eventually open a Newark dessert shop. And Herbert has been crowned with lifelong celebrity chef status.

“It definitely changes things,” says the Bear resident. “What TV does, it puts a stamp on what you’ve already been doing. It introduces you to people that are outside of Delaware, and even inside Delaware. It really gets you out there and gets you known for what you loved doing.”

Read more here.

search_result.title: Election Day 2022 in Delaware: Race results tallied as polls close
search_result.text:
Election Day in Delaware was largely uneventful Tuesday, though at least 10 Delaware polling places saw temporary voting delays after the locations briefly ran out of the "activation slips that pull up the electronic ballot on the machine," according to state Election Day spokesperson Mat Marshall.

In most cases, Marshall said, more activation slips were delivered within 10 minutes, allowing voting to resume. By the time polls closed at 8 p.m., more than 320,000 votes had been cast statewide.

About 77,000 of those came from early voting.

While the election is an important one nationally with Republicans expected to take control of the U.S. House of Representatives ‒ as of 11 p.m. Tuesday, it remained a tossup which party will control the U.S. Senate ‒ races in the First State this year were largely uncontroversial.

This differed from the 2020 election, where a Delaware man was vying for the presidency and Lauren Witzke attempted to unseat U.S. Sen. Chris Coons. (Only one of them was successful).

Prep for the polls: See who is running for president and compare where they stand on key issues in our Voter Guide

Incumbents U.S. Rep. Lisa Blunt Rochester, Attorney General Kathy Jennings and State Treasurer Colleen Davis all won by at least seven percentage points on Tuesday, and Democrat Lydia York was elected as state auditor, according to the state elections website.

While every lawmaker in the General Assembly was up for reelection this year due to redistricting, the political makeup of Delaware's legislature didn't change much.

“With Delaware such a blue state, there may be some insulation for a lot of these races,” Paul Brewer, a University of Delaware political science professor, told Delaware Online/The News Journal ahead of Tuesday.

Delaware Online/The News Journal kept track of election happenings in the First State on Tuesday:

WHERE TO FIND ELECTION RESULTS:2022 Delaware Election Results

Democratic Kent County Sheriff loses to Republican opponent

Kent County Democratic Sheriff Brian Lewis was upset by his Republican challenger in a three-way race on Tuesday, according to the state election website.

Norman Barlow received about 53% of the vote. Lewis received 44% and non-Partisan candidate Aarika Nelson received just under 2%.

Democrats predicted to win in Delaware statewide offices

Three Democrats are predicted to win the statewide offices of Delaware attorney general, auditor of accounts and state treasurer.

As of 10:30 p.m., with 511 of Delaware's 516 precincts reporting, incumbent Attorney General Kathy Jennings, auditor candidate Lydia York and treasurer incumbent Colleen Davis are all leading their Republican opponents by at least seven percentage points.

MORE ABOUT THE RACES:Democrats declare victory in Delaware attorney general, auditor and treasurer races

At a Democratic watch party in downtown Wilmington, all declared victory.

Gov. John Carney and other elected officials, including Lt. Gov. Bethany Hall-Long, praised the female representation among the statewide races, including state auditor, attorney general and treasurer.

“We call this the woman wave,” Carney said at the watch party.

Two hours after Delaware polls close, only one race called

Two hours after the polls closed in Delaware, the only race called was the U.S. House of Representatives ‒ for incumbent Lisa Blunt Rochester.

As of 10 p.m., 469 of 516 precincts had reported and about 303,500 votes had been counted.

Maryland elects first Black governor

Bestselling author Wes Moore has become Maryland's first Black governor.

He faced Trump endorsee Dan Cox. Cox has also promoted the former president’s lies about the election. During the insurrection on Jan. 6, 2021, Cox tweeted that Vice President Mike Pence was a “traitor.”

Moore’s victory flips a governor’s office from Republican to Democratic.

Maryland voters also voted to legalize marijuana for those 21 and older on Tuesday. It's now the 20th state to legalize week for adult use.

Associated Press calls Delaware U.S. House race for incumbent

Lisa Blunt Rochester will serve a fourth term as Delaware's lone representative in the U.S. House after defeating Republican Lee Murphy in Tuesday's election.

Blunt Rochester, who became Delaware's first federal representative of color and first woman in Congress in 2016, was the projected winner as polls closed in Delaware.

The Congresswoman billed herself to voters as a problem solver invested in her community and someone who can find common ground with opponents. Among her legislative priorities are reversing climate change and providing affordable health care. She also campaigned on codifying abortion rights and hailed her role in passing the Inflation Reduction Act, which she says will help Delaware families by lowering prescription drug prices and energy costs.

— Brandon Holveck

Polls close in Delaware, elsewhere across the country

Polls in Delaware and elsewhere nationwide closed at 8 p.m., though as of 8:20 p.m., only Delaware early votes (both absentee and in-person) had been reported.

The early votes show U.S. Rep. Lisa Blunt Rochester clinching the seat as expected, with 66% of the early vote. Her Republican opponent, Lee Murphy, received 33% of early votes.

In a similar percentage breakdown, incumbent Attorney General Kathy Jennings received 64% of the early vote while Republican Julianne Murray received 36%.

State auditor Democratic candidate Lydia York is leading over her Republican opponent Janice Lorrah in early voting, 65% to 35%, respectively.

State auditor candidate makes her rounds on Tuesday, some voting machines acting up

Before stopping by the Skyline Middle School polling location, Democratic candidate for state auditor Lydia York visited one of the Delaware Democrats offices in Pike Creek to thank volunteers who were running the phones Tuesday.

York said while she is still anxious to know the results, she’s been encouraged by the high voter turnout as she visited polling sites up and down the state.

That turnout was represented at the nearby Skyline Middle School, where candidates and volunteers said they saw lines extending along the sidewalk until about 11 a.m. The wait time could be about an hour at its longest Tuesday morning, but voters were in and out quickly around 4:30 p.m.

Morgan Wright, an intern with Common Cause Delaware ‒ which leads the Election Protection Program to make sure everyone can vote without any barriers ‒ said the morning backup was due in part to technical difficulties. When someone touched a candidate’s name on the screen, it would highlight a different name. Usually that name was under the same party, Wright said, but navigating that technical challenge still resulted in some delays.

Wright and volunteer Christine DeBrabander will stay at Skyline until the polls close at 8 p.m. to ensure everyone can vote and the doors stay open until closing time.

One of the voters who showed up at Skyline as dusk was arriving was Adam Woo, who said he's been bringing his children with him to vote since they were newborns.

He always comes out to vote, but politics today have especially motivated him to vote Democrat.

“The Republican Party has just gone full fascist and, whether you're leftist or liberal, you have to just fight that. So it's not about any issues anymore,” he said.

— Emily Lytle

What to watch for in New Castle County

The two legislative races to keep an eye on in New Castle County are the county sheriff and county council District 2 positions.

Vying for sheriff are incumbent Scott Philips, a Democrat, and non-partisan affiliate John Machurek.

Machurek previously ran as a libertarian candidate for governor in 2020, Delaware attorney general in 2014 and for District 16 of the state House of Representatives in 2012. Machurek lost all of the races in landslide numbers.

Phillips has served as New Castle County Sheriff since 2019. Prior to being elected, he had 13 years of experience as deputy sheriff and another 10 years in law enforcement with New Castle County police as a patrol officer and detective.

In the New Castle County Council District 2 race, Republican Jamie Collins is challenging Democratic incumbent Dee Durham.

Durham has held the seat since 2018. A long-standing conservationist, the Democrat has sponsored legislative action aimed at getting Delaware closer to its energy goals, including requiring new homes in New Castle County to be equipped with electric vehicle charging infrastructure.

According to Collins’ website, the Republican challenger is running on a campaign advocating for job creation and projects to “energize the County” while respecting the environment. Collins also plans to propose a resolution for the state to begin capturing revenue from online sports gambling.

Collins is known partly for his late father, Richard T. Collins. The elder Collins was elected state auditor in 1974 and New Castle County Executive in 1980.

— Molly McVety

Residents reiterate: Voting is 'our civic duty'

A slow but steady trickle of voters came out to cast their ballots at the Route 9 Library and Innovation Center in New Castle on Tuesday.

"It's our civic duty and it's necessary, especially with what's going on in our country today," one voter said.

Dionne Daniels, 47, felt this urgency when she came out to vote. She hasn't voted in a general election since Barack Obama was on the ballot, but said it's important now that she makes her voice heard.

Daniels said Delawareans should come out to vote, even though it's not a presidential election. If not, someone may be elected who doesn't look out for "everyone's best interests."

At the nearby polling place of DeLaWarr State Service Center, one Black voter said she's casting her ballot because "our people died for it."

Both the library and the state service center had lines of paint or tape in the parking lot 50 feet away from the doors. Non-voters, including pollsters, media or potential voter intimidators, had to stay behind them. However, no one else was waiting outside.

In Elsmere, it was relatively quiet outside the fire hall and Baltz Elementary School, but a small and contingent of individuals streamed into and out of Town Hall.

After voting, Abar Brown walked out with a look of determination and a message: “Everybody needs to vote today.”

Was there any particular issue that concerned the seven-year resident of the town? No, just everything that is making headlines, including abortion, he said.

Brittany Christian, 37, moved to Elsmere almost a year ago from Philadelphia and said she was voting to have a voice.

"I don't want to be in the position where I'm complaining about things going on around me, but not actively participating and making it better," she said. "I'm not really one to complain, but I love to do my part. I'm just excited to participate.”

— Hannah Edelman and Anitra Johnson

Nearly 200,000 votes cast by midday Tuesday

As of 12:30 p.m. on Election Day, 195,955 Delawareans had voted in the election, with 116,549 people voting in person on Tuesday, according to state officials.

So far, New Castle County, the most populated county in Delaware, is leading the number of people who have cast ballots. Registered Democrats are also outpacing their Republican counterparts. So far, 51,262 registered Democrats have voted compared to 42,843 Republicans.

Nearly 77,000 ballots were cast during early voting in Delaware, according to election data.

Election officials reported that 76,977 Delawareans voted from Oct. 28 to Nov. 6 – both in the form of absentee ballot and in-person early voting. This makes up roughly 10% of registered voters.

This is the first election in which the state allowed for early voting. A total of 55,532 ballots were cast in person during this voting period, with the most taking place in Sussex County. Democrats also outnumbered Republicans by about 12,000 votes.

The only option available to Delawareans is to vote in person, either early or on Election Day, or vote by absentee ballot. In order to vote absentee, a resident must provide a valid excuse as to why they cannot vote in person.

Earlier this fall, the Delaware Supreme Court found voting by mail and registering to vote on Election Day to be unconstitutional. Both of these were previously allowed during the primary in September but are now no longer options for Delawareans.

Unlike other states, Delaware is expected to tally its votes quickly. In the 2020 election, results were first reported about 15 minutes after polls closed. About 90% of results were in by 10:15 p.m., according to the Associated Press.

Election officials can start counting absentee ballots the Friday before Election Day, but the state cannot release counts until after the polls close at 8 p.m. on Tuesday.

— Meredith Newman

Sussex County voter turns heads in military truck

Voters trickled in steadily at Georgetown Elementary School around noon on Tuesday, with at least one making a head-turning entrance.

Tim Collard of Milton pulled up to the location in a military truck with flags that said "Biden Sucks" and "Trump 2024." He said he bought it from a government surplus sale.

"It's been in parades but it's also a work truck, sort of," Collard said. "At least I tell my wife that."

Also voting at Georgetown Elementary – though for the other party – was 69-year-old Michael Makowski, who said he feels the country is at a "crossroads."

"We can either take the bad route and become more authoritarian or try to maintain the democracy we have," Makowski said. "I voted Democratic because I think the Democrats are more concerned with preserving the democracy than Republicans."

The future of the country was also top-of-mind for voters in Brandywine Hundred in New Castle County.

Shelly Towler, who cast her vote at Brandywine High School, said the direction the Republican Party took under former President Donald Trump led her to recently re-register, changing her party from Republican to Independent.

“The party stands for nothing that I used to think it stood for,” Towler said.

She came to the polls with the Supreme Court’s recent reversal of abortion rights on her mind. She’s also discouraged by the Republican party’s attitude toward voting rights and the integrity of democracy.

“It’s a huge embarrassment. We are supposed to be the example?” Towler said. “It’s just going backwards in time.”

A steady stream of voters followed Towler to the polls on a brisk morning as crunchy leaves blown by the wind scratched the school parking lot. The school is one of several polling places in the fifth state senate district, which a Democrat won in 2020 for the first time in more than 40 years.

At nearby Emmanuel Presbyterian Church, Dennis Quill said he voted for Democrats down the ballot. The country needs to ensure individuals’ right to an abortion, Quill said, and he’s disappointed by the partisan justices on the Supreme Court, a body he is in favor of broadening or term limits.

“I wouldn’t vote for a Republican if my life depended on it,” Quill said.

Quill said he hopes voters realize “things aren’t as bad as people think” and are motivated to support candidates who can keep the nation from a deeper slide. But he’s more focused on races in neighboring states and the national landscape than Delaware, where he expects Democrats to win easily.

Paul Donohue will just be happy when political ads are off his TV. Like Quill, he says “it doesn’t really feel like Delaware has any impact races.” But that hasn’t kept other races, like the battle between John Fetterman and Mehmet Oz for Pennsylvania’s Senate seat, off his screen.

“I find it pretty upsetting that they’re all mean,” Donohue said. “They don’t talk about the issues much, they just attack each other. I’ll be thankful when it’s over.”

— Brandon Holveck, Shannon Marvel McNaught

What to watch for in Sussex County

The most-watched races in Sussex this year will likely be the Senate District 6 and Representative District 20 races.

District 6 Republican Sen. Ernie Lopez is retiring this year, and District 20 Republican Rep. Steve Smyk is giving up his seat to run for Lopez’s. Both seats are longtime Republican strongholds in a county where only one legislator, House Speaker Pete Schwartzkopf, is a Democrat.

Smyk faces Democrat Russ Huxtable and Gwendolyn Jones (Non-Partisan Delaware) in the Senate District 6 race. In the Representative District 20 race, Democrat Stell Parker Selby and Republican Dallas Wingate are running.

In Representative District 20, as of this month, registered Democrats outnumber Republicans 8,423 to 7,742. There are also 5,444 independents. That’s compared to 9,802 Democrats, 9,591 Republicans and 6,430 independents in 2020.

In Senate District 6, there are 18,942 Democrats, 15,770 Republicans and 11,471 independents. In 2020, there were 10,282 Democrats, 8,229 Republicans and 5,751 independents.

Senate District 6 includes Rehoboth Beach, Lewes and Milton. Representative District 20 includes most of Lewes, Milton and parts of Georgetown.

— Shannon Marvel McNaught

Voters struggle to get to polling location due to road blockage

Voters near Townsend were unable to get to Blackbird Community Center Tuesday morning due to Verizon blocking the road.

An election day spokesperson later told Delaware Online/The News Journal that "elections has indicated that it is aware and is in the process of addressing the blockage."

Steady turnout at the polls Tuesday morning

Across the state Tuesday morning, polling locations saw a steady stream of voters.

There was a line outside Clayton Fire Company just before the polls opened at 7 a.m. Among the first voters was Diana Dede.

She said the issue she’s been following the most has been the debate about guns, saying “it’s just important to me to vote.”

Paul Skreenock, also one of the first in line, said he didn’t come to the polls for a specific issue or candidate but because “it’s my civic duty.”

In Wilmington, there was only one voter at the Delaware Technical Community College polling place just after 8 a.m. On the outside, the only sign that it was Election Day was the red poster indicating the entrance to the polling place.

Two seniors walked out of the voting area as a reporter walked in. According to a poll worker, this was the calm after a morning rush when the polls opened at 7 a.m. There were no issues with the voting machines, as the process took less than a minute.

About an hour later in Dover, the parking lot at East Dover Elementary wasn't busy as residents turned out to cast their vote. Yolanda Poe, 53, of Dover, said her decision to vote was, in part, to set a precedent for her grandchildren.

“For centuries as Black people, we couldn't vote and women couldn't do anything," Poe said after casting her vote. "Now we have the right to, so it's important that we do something."

In front of the elementary school, she took a selfie with Kerri Evelyn Harris, a candidate for Delaware State Representative. Harris, shivering from the cold, was the only candidate greeting voters outside the school at 9 a.m.

An older woman who slowly walked toward the school’s entrance to vote told Harris: “Keep warm!”

To the north in Talleyville, a handful of residents were voting at Springer Middle School at 10 a.m.

One poll worker said about 170 people had voted so far Tuesday morning, but about a half-dozen more walked in less than five minutes after the poll worker gave his estimate.

— Ben Mace, Isabel Hughes, Andre Lamar, Meredith Newman

Why Lee Murphy thinks he can upset Lisa Blunt Rochester

A Republican hasn’t represented Delaware in Congress since 2011, but Lee Murphy, the party’s challenger to Lisa Blunt Rochester, is confident that will soon change.

“I’ve lived here a long time,” Murphy said by phone Monday. “I’ve seen Democrats rule the state, Republicans be in power. For many years in this state, Republicans and Democrats worked together, but that recently hasn’t been the case. I just believe one-party rule, especially over a long period of time, isn't healthy for everyone.”

Murphy, who voted Tuesday morning at Hillcrest-Bellefont Methodist Church off Marsh Road just outside of Wilmington, said his No. 1 issue is the economy. Voters he’s spoken with are hurting from record inflation and are concerned about oil prices ahead of the winter months, he said.

READ:3 takeaways from the Blunt Rochester-Murphy U.S House debate

It’s an issue he hopes energizes voters to seek change.

Blunt Rochester won Delaware’s lone seat in the U.S. House of Representatives in 2016 after fellow Democrat John Carney left the office to seek the governorship. Murphy has run in each election since, challenging Scott Walker unsuccessfully for the Republican nomination in 2018 before losing to Blunt Rochester in the general election in 2020.

The indicators once again point in Blunt Rochester’s favor.

A poll conducted by the University of Delaware Center for Political Communication published in October found 50% of registered voters plan to vote for Blunt Rochester and 33% support Murphy.

Blunt Rochester’s campaign has raised almost $2.7 million, about nine times as much as Murphy’s.

Murphy pointed to the Delaware Supreme Court’s ruling against vote-by-mail and same-day voter registration as a reason for optimism. Without the COVID-19 measures that expanded absentee voting by mailing ballots to registered voters in 2020 and the following two years of Joe Biden's presidency, Murphy believes he’s better positioned this year compared to previous runs.

“This election is very much a referendum on Joe Biden, which is bad for the Democrats,” Murphy said. “The landscape has definitely changed.”

— Brandon Holveck

What to watch for on Tuesday

While Delaware races may be lower-stakes this year than in past years, elsewhere across the country there are a number of hot races that many are watching.

Here are some that will determine what the country looks like moving forward:

Pennsylvania races to watch

In neighboring Pennsylvania, all eyes are on the U.S. Senate and gubernatorial races.

The outcome of the Senate race, between Lt. Gov. John Fetterman and Dr. Mehmet Oz, could determine the balance of power in the U.S. Senate, ultimately affecting issues like abortion rights and the economy, among others.

For the governor’s race, Democratic candidate and Pennsylvania Attorney General Josh Shapiro faces Doug Mastriano, a far-right Trump-endorsee who has supported the former president’s lies that the election was stolen.

MIDTERMS ARE HERE:Midterms are less than a week away. Here are the key races in Delaware

Maryland races to watch

In Maryland, bestselling author Wes Moore, who would become the state’s first Black governor if elected, is facing another Trump endorsee, Dan Cox. Cox has also promoted the former president’s lies about the election. During the insurrection on Jan. 6, 2021, Cox tweeted that Vice President Mike Pence was a “traitor.”

Moore is seen as the favorite to clinch the gubernatorial election in Maryland.

New York races to watch

To Delaware's north, it's unlikely that the traditionally blue state of New York will look much different after Tuesday. Still, the governor's race between Gov. Kathy Hochul ‒ the state's first female governor who took over following disgraced Gov. Andrew Cuomo's resignation last year ‒ and Republican Rep. Lee Zeldin isn't a shoo-in.

Hochul's lead over Trump-backed Zeldin has narrowed in recent weeks, according to Politico's election forecast.

Georgia races to watch

Many eyes are on Georgia's governor's race this year, a repeat matchup between Gov. Brian Kemp and gubernatorial hopeful Stacey Abrams.

Recent polls show Kemp ‒ no longer the overseer of Georgia's elections as he was during the 2018 race ‒ leading by seven percentage points. Still, Abrams was able to mobilize many voters in 2018, something she hopes to carry with her this year.

KEMP VS ABRAMS:In second debate, Georgia candidates Kemp and Abrams argue over abortion, gun control

Just as anticipated, though slightly more contentious, is Georgia's U.S. Senate race.

Democratic incumbent Sen. Raphael Warnock is facing Trump-backed Herschel Walker, an anti-abortion advocate who, in recent weeks, has repeatedly denied that he paid for two women to have abortions years ago. The women recently came forward with the claims that Walker impregnated them and then paid for the medical procedures.

Earlier in his campaign, Walker revealed that he fathered four children by four different women, a striking contrast to his public admonishments about absentee fathers and his previous contention that he had three children, USA Today reported.

According to FiveThirtyEight, the race is quite close, with Walker leading Warnock by about one percentage point.

Arizona races to watch

Arizona's gubernatorial race remains a toss-up, but it will be closely watched.

Polls are showing election denier Kari Lake slightly ahead of incumbent Democrat Gov. Katie Hobbs, though that may not mean much. The veracity of polls often depends on what entity is conducting them, what their methods are and whether they have a partisan lean.

POLLS AREN'T ALWAYS ACCURATE:Polls in Arizona's Senate and governor's races: Don't count on them

The outcome of the gubernatorial race will have important implications ahead of the 2024 presidential election.

Lake, a former local Fox News anchor who now markets herself as an anti-media Republican, has repeatedly reiterated the baseless claim that Trump won the 2020 election in Arizona. She's also said she would not have certified President Joe Biden's election if she were governor at the time.

Florida races to watch

As in many other states, Florida's key contests are the gubernatorial and U.S. Senate races.

Incumbent Gov. Ron DeSantis, who will likely be a presidential contender in 2024, is facing off against Charlie Crist, a former Republican governor-turned-Democrat who represented Florida in the U.S. House of Representatives until August of this year. He resigned to focus on the governor's race.

DELAWARE'S MIGRANT PLANE THAT WASN'T:'No reports of anyone arriving' after rumors of DeSantis' incoming migrant plane

On the U.S. Senate side of the midterms, Republican Marco Rubio, a senator since 2011, is facing off against Democrat Val Demings. Polls show Rubio with a more than eight percentage point lead.

Ohio races to watch

This election cycle, U.S. Rep. Tim Ryan ‒ who is vying for Ohio's U.S. Senate seat ‒ has out-raised many other Senate hopefuls across the nation.

READ:Tim Ryan is raising more than J.D. Vance. Can he counter national GOP spending?

Yet it remains to be seen whether Ryan's cash flow will be enough to secure him the race against Trump-backed Republican J.D. Vance.

search_result.title: Year in review: Stories of 2018 that brought change to South Jersey
search_result.text:
Trying to keep up with the news around here could give you a case of information whiplash.

Changes in New Jersey came rapidly during 2018, starting with the inauguration of Gov. Phil Murphy to replace colorful, controversial Chris Christie.

The developments continued as the state moved closer to legalizing marijuana and banning plastic bags. And New Jersey's legal arguments convinced the Supreme Court to clear the way for sports betting across the land.

Events unfolding in South Jersey reflected national themes such as the opioid crisis, reflections on race and the push to raise the minimum wage. Many of these stories will have an impact beyond 2018:

Camden landmarks come down

The long-anticipated — and for some, long-dreaded — demolition of iconic Camden High began early in the year. A number of legal challenges could not save the century-old "Castle on the Hill," which school district officials maintained would be too expensive repair.

The district did solicit feedback from Camden High students, alumni, staff and city residents on a design for the new school, which is set to open in 2021. The recommended concept for the state-of-the-art learning academy will pay homage to the old school.

As 2018 drew to a close, another high-profile Camden site also faced a transition. A demolition contract was awarded in December for Campbell's Field, which housed the Camden Riversharks independent baseball team through 2015. The stadium, which struggled with attendance over 15 seasons, will be reduced to rubble by spring.

The site, owned by the Camden County Improvement Authority, has most recently been used by Rutgers University–Camden's Division III Scarlet Raptors baseball team. Going forward, the waterfront property will house athletic fields and facilities for Rutgers University–Camden and the City of Camden.

Burlco goes blue

Democrats gained ground in the 2018 midterm election — and that trend was evident in South Jersey. Traditionally Republican Burlington County elected two Democratic freeholders and a Democratic county clerk.

Democrats also picked up two council seats each in races in Evesham, Mount Laurel, Maple Shade and Moorestown, and Evesham's next mayor will be Democrat Jaclyn Veasy, replacing the GOP's Randy Brown, who declined to run for re-election.

Democratic newcomer Andy Kim defeated incumbent Rep. Tom MacArthur, a Republican, in the state's 3rd District, which includes much of Burlington and Ocean counties. And state Sen. Jeff Van Drew, a Democrat, won South Jersey's 2nd District, where Republican U.S. Rep. Frank LoBiondo is retiring.

The political shift left just one Republican, the 4th District's Chris Smith, among New Jersey's 12 congressional districts.

Festivals come and go

Rising costs motivated organizers of the Mercer County Italian American Festival to move the event to Burlington County after 18 years. The vast three-day festival had its South Jersey debut in September on the 65-acre Burlington County Fairgrounds in Columbus. Visitors had access to an Italian Market craft fair, a "food piazza" and wine and beer gardens; entertainment and a kids' zone. The festival is known for a 50/50 raffle with a generous jackpot; the 2018 winner took home $9,249.

For the first time in two decades, Haddonfield will welcome a new year without its traditional First Night celebration. Organizers announced in August that they had retired the family-friendly event, which featured fireworks and performances at downtown venues. Citing declining interest in the festival, organizer and former Haddonfield mayor Jack Tarditi said the borough will look into other ways to usher in the new year.

Football firing draws heat

For years, the Camden Catholic football team was best known for being a winning program with a long tradition. That all changed in April, when five-year head coach Nick Strom made stunning allegations of racial bias following his firing. Strom, who is white, said officials had an issue with him because he had too many black players on his team.

A number of players protested Strom's firing, and some left the program.

Officials denied the racial accusations, but the story drew national attention and spurred leadership changes at the school. The coach hired to replace Strom, Cody Hall, resigned in November. Interim coach Gary Onuekwusi took over the program after that.

The story was one of several racial controversies at South Jersey schools that spurred discussion, ramifications and soul-searching over the past year.

Cherry Hill High School East's principal apologized for "inappropriateness" of wording on prom tickets that urged students to "party like it's 1776" at the National Constitution Center. African-American groups complained that the phrase was insensitive because it referenced a period when blacks would have been slaves.

Haddonfield Memorial High's boys lacrosse season was canceled as state civil rights officials investigated a report of a racial slur. Sterling High School said one of the lacrosse team members hurled the offensive insult during a track meet.

And state wrestling official Alan Maloney, who used a racial epithet to describe a fellow ref in 2016, drew outrage again when he ordered a Buena High wrestler to cut his dreadlocks or forfeit a match. A video of the incident catapulted the controversy into a national story. The New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association and the New Jersey Division on Civil Rights are investigating the matter. At an emergency meeting called by the Buena Regional Board of Education, Superintendent David Cappuccio Jr. said he notified the NJSIAA that Buena wrestlers would not participate in matches where Maloney was officiating.

More to minimum wage

Gov. Phil Murphy has urged the state legislature to establish a $15-per-hour minimum wage for New Jersey.

But hospitals that are among the state's largest employers aren't waiting for a mandate.

Cooper University Health Care committed in November to raise its minimum wage to $15. Two weeks later, Jefferson Health said it would meet the $15 threshold in 2019. And Virtua announced in December it would bump its minimum wage to $15.15.

A spokesman for Inspira Health has said the South Jersey health system also is working to raise its minimum wage.

The health-care industry isn't alone in paying workers more.

Energy-technology firm Holtec, which moved its South Jersey campus from Mount Laurel to Camden in 2017, will introduce a $15 minimum wage at its three U.S. plants on Jan. 1.

Amazon also was among the New Jersey employers that raised its minimum wage to $15 in 2018.

Narcan availability expands

First responders from Cooper University Hospital were called to 5,000 confirmed or suspected overdoses in 2017. That staggering number points to the opioid crisis throughout Camden County, and helped spur a partnership between county officials and area hospital systems to distribute the opioid antidote naloxone, also known by the brand name Narcan.

Law enforcement and health-care systems each have a role in the initiative, announced in March. Cooper Health, Jefferson Health New Jersey and Virtua Health will buy naloxone in bulk, saving the county 50 percent. The Camden County Prosecutor's Office will then distribute the antidote to police departments throughout the county as needed.

The Camden County effort mirrors those that have been underway in other parts of South Jersey since 2015.

Inspira Health and Jefferson supply law enforcement agencies and police departments in Gloucester County with the opioid antidote. Virtua Health, Deborah Heart and Lung Center and Lourdes Health System work with Burlington County police departments and law enforcement to provide naloxone.

Medical marijuana sites double

New Jersey has just six dispensaries to serve the 38,000 patients enrolled in its medical marijuana program. But the state Health Department solicited applications in the fall so it could double the number of sites.

Demand was strong — nearly 150 applicants from across the country and Canada competed for the six new slots. The state announced its selections in December, including the two applicants that would serve South Jersey.

Columbia Care New Jersey can now apply to grow and dispense medical marijuana in Vineland. And MPX New Jersey can apply to grow marijuana in Galloway Township and dispense the medication in nearby Atlantic City.

Both Vineland and Atlantic City had demonstrated their support for medical marijuana programs.

In November, Vineland residents approved a referendum to allow medical marijuana grow facilities and dispensaries in the city.

And the MPX application included letters of support from the Atlantic City Mayor's Office and the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority.

Other South Jersey towns reacted to the prospect of medical marijuana sites by changing zoning laws, and adopting ordinances either supporting or opposing local pot facilities.

EDA approves tax breaks

The state's Economic Development Authority backed tens of millions of dollars worth of incentives to keep or lure business in South Jersey.

The beneficiaries included Camden Yards Steel, which received $5.4 million in tax breaks to keep 32 jobs and create eight new jobs in Camden; and Union Packaging LLC, which picked up a $10.6 million incentive while considering a move from Yeadon, Pa., to Camden that would bring 65 jobs to the city.

Business services firm Corcentric is getting a $1.4 million incentive to expand to a new Cherry Hill facility, adding 20 jobs.

Gobrands Inc., a company that expanded its goPuff convenience delivery service to South Jersey when it opened a Cherry Hill warehouse last summer, earned a $39 million tax break to centralize its operations near Rowan University. The company is promising to bring 600 jobs to the 300,000-square-foot facility on Route 322.

The pharmaceutical industry has typically been a big industry in other parts of the state, but an $8.4 million EDA incentive could bring specialty medication firm Chemistry RX to Camden. The Philadelphia company could create 56 jobs by moving to the former city library on Federal Street.

Project targets rundown Camden area

Recent years have seen a development boom along the Camden Waterfront and in the "eds and meds" corridor around Broadway. But the Camden County Improvement Authority is now targeting one of Camden's oldest neighborhoods for redevelopment.

The stretch of Haddon Avenue in the city's Gateway area is pocked by abandoned homes and vacant lots. The CCIA said developers "may propose (a) mixed-use residential concept." However, county spokesman Dan Keashen described the request for bids in September as an "exploratory process" and said the county would await concepts before speculating on the future of the neighborhood.

A redevelopment agreement could be signed within the first few months of 2019. In the meantime, the county also is pursuing a study on potential major redevelopment along Haddon Avenue in in the Gateway, Whitman Park and Parkside neighborhoods.

Struggling mall gets plan

It was once among South Jersey's thriving shopping areas. Now it's a ghost town, even during the holiday season.

So what will become of Voorhees Town Center, formerly the Echelon Mall?

Months after the township's planning board advanced a plan to allow eminent domain at the site, a conditional redeveloper was named. Brandywine Financial Services Corp., a Philadelphia-area real estate company, is expected to transform the mall into a mixed-use center with housing and entertainment attractions.

Sheri Berkery: @SheriBerkery; 856-486-2673; sberkery@gannettnj.com
