search_result.title: Erie School District poised to hire turnaround specialist to aid ...
search_result.text:
Erie School Board to vote to hire national firm in school district's effort to stem academic decline at Erie High

School district would use nearly $554,000 in federal pandemic aid on two-year plan

Turnaround specialist would assist teachers, administrators on techniques to address problems that worsened during COVID-19 outbreak

The Erie School District is prepared to hire an education turnaround specialist to help spur a transformation of Erie High, the district's largest and most academically troubled school.

The district wants to use $553,800 in federal pandemic relief aid to pay for WestEd, a San Francisco-based educational research firm, to carry out a two-year plan at Erie High.

Engaging students:Civics matter. How civics education in Erie school districts encourages student engagement

WestEd would work with teachers and administrators to develop techniques to reverse Erie High's academic decline and to better address social and emotional issues that many of the school's 2,215 students are dealing with. WestEd would tailor its approach to the needs of Erie High, including working on the curriculum.

The administration of Erie schools Superintendent Brian Polito is asking the Erie School Board to vote to hire WestEd at the board's monthly meeting on Wednesday at 6 p.m. at East Middle School.

Administration officials gave a presentation on WestEd at the board's nonvoting study session this past Wednesday. No board members objected to the hiring at the study session.

WestEd's involvement offers the best way for the Erie High to recover and end the risk of state oversight due to its poor academic performance, district administrators said. They said WestEd, a national nonprofit with more than 1,100 employees, has aided the rapid turnaround of schools in other cities, including Buffalo.

"We know that Erie High is not operating at the capacity it can be," Teresa Szumigala, the assistant Erie schools superintendent who handles academics, said in an interview. "The ultimate goal is to strengthen our practices and improve our outcomes in all areas."

Why does the Erie School District want to bring in a consultant?

The district has focused on improving Erie High since the district created it in 2017 by merging three high schools, largely for financial reasons. East High School and Strong Vincent High School were consolidated on the site of what had been Central High School, 3325 Cherry St., which the district renamed Erie High. Northwest Pennsylvania Collegiate Academy remains a separate high school.

The efforts to fix Erie High took on more urgency in January. The state Department of Education placed it in a federal category known as A-TSI, for Additional Targeted Support and Improvement.

To be categorized as A-TSI, a school must have one or more student groups that are performing below the level of schools designated as CSI, for Comprehensive Support and Improvement.

The academic performance for a CSI school is so poor that the school gets a a state-appointed improvement facilitator, according to Pennsylvania guidelines. A CSI school has a graduation rate of 67% or lower or is in the bottom 5% academically for all students in Title I schools, which have a high percentage of students who live in poverty.

Erie High's situation is similar to that of the district's Pfeiffer-Burleigh Elementary School years ago. It underwent an intense program to boost its students academic performance as a CSI school.

The only other Erie School District school labeled an A-TSI school in January is East Middle School. Polito said its problems areas are fewer than those at Erie High, and that the school district will develop an in-house turnaround plan for East.

What are some education statistics for Erie High?

The CSI, A-TSI designations and other labels are part of the federal Every Student Succeeds Act, which became law in 2015. It replaced the No Child Left Behind Act, which became law in 2002.

Expanding experiences:'An exciting time': Erie High works to re-energize career and technical education

A total of 70.3.% of Erie High seniors graduated within four years in 2021-22, up from 64.3% in 2020-21, according to district data. A total of 72.7% of Erie High seniors graduated within five years in 2021-22, up from 71.6% in 2020-21, according to the data.

Erie High's A-TSI designation has more to do with the school's overall academic performance than it does with graduation rates, according to the criteria for an A-TSI tag.

According to state data, 11.7% of the students scored proficient or advanced — or recorded passing scores — in language arts on the Keystone Exams in 2021-22.

A total of 6.3% of Erie High students scored proficient or advanced in math and algebra, and 11.5% scored proficient or advanced in math in science and biology.

State data also shows 83% of Erie High students were listed as economically disadvantaged as of June 2022. The racial breakdown of Erie High, according to the data as of June 2022, was 41% Black, 35.3% white, 14.5% Hispanic, 4.5% Asian, approximately 0.3% of other races or ethnicities and 4.5% of two or more races.

The Erie School District also cited disciplinary concerns at Erie High. The administration said it is looking to WestEd to help limit those problems.

As of the third quarter of the 2022-23 school year, 26% of the students at Erie High had been suspended at least on day, according to district data. The district classified 48.4% of the students as chronically absent.

How did the pandemic affect Erie High?

As the Erie High saw its students academic performance decline during the pandemic, the school has struggled with social problems that officials said festered during the outbreak, when students lacked structure as they took classes online rather than in the classroom.

One student shot another student in a hallway at Erie High in April 2022, and students at Erie High and other district schools have been caught up in other youth violence that has plagued Erie during and after the pandemic — a period during which youth gangs have proliferated, according to Erie police and court records.

"The pandemic caused some of these issues," Polito said. He said the correlation is why the district can use the $553,800 in pandemic-related federal funds to pay for WestEd. The money is from the district's American Rescue Plan allocation.

"We have never had the opportunity to do anything like this because our finances were so tight," Polito told the School Board at the study session this past Wednesday. "We do have the stimulus funds."

He was referring to the 10,000-student Erie School District's protracted financial crisis, which ended when the state removed it from financial oversight in September.

Polito and other administrators said WestEd will help Erie High look at different ways to address students' social and emotional needs.

Change in fortune:Erie School District removed from financial oversight as state praises turnaround

Erie High will be designated an A-TSI school for three years before the state evaluates its progress. The Erie School District hopes WestEd, if hired, will get the school out of the classification, and keep it out of a CSI designation.

Where case stands:A year after Erie High shooting, a plea deal could be near for teen defendant

"We want to be proactive in moving the school in a new direction academically," Polito said in an interview. "They have a track record of turning around schools just like Erie High," he said of WestEd. "We thought Erie High would benefit from having a team like them to work with."

What do the administrators and teachers think of WestEd?

WestEd's team will work closely with the Erie High administration, particularly its principal, Don Orlando. Polito and Szumigala, the assistant superintendent, stressed that the push to bring in WestEd was not meant to be a criticism of the teachers and administrators at Erie High. They said WestEd's involvement would be designed to help those who work at Erie High every day.

Orlando said he welcomes the additional support.

"I'm very excited to have this partnership," Orlando told the School Board at the study session this past Wednesday. "We are lifelong learners. Improvement never stops, never ends. We feel we are on the verge of doing a lot of great things and we are already headed in a positive direction this school year.

"But we are open to having someone come in and take a look at our practices and make sure we are doing best practices in every area of our building and help us make those changes," Orlando said. "Because our community and kids deserve the best high school they can have and we are open to whatever it takes to do that."

The Erie Education Association teachers' union was part of the discussions to bring in WestEd, Polito said. When asked about the proposal to bring in WestEd, the president of the 840-member EEA, Mary Theuerkauf, said:

Latest youth violence:Testimony reveals gang beef led to 14-year-old's shooting on Cherry Street in Erie

"There is a lot to examine and it's a complex situation, but the solution must improve the time we spend with the students. We need to nurture them back from the pandemic.

"That experience brought into stark focus how much these children need their teachers and how critical the school environment is to their safety and wellbeing. We need to create a new culture of learning. And Erie teachers and education specialists are up to that challenge."

Possible tax increase at Erie School District

The Erie School District has a June 30 deadline to pass a budget for 2023-24, but the School Board is indicating it favors a tax increase of 2.46%.

A majority of the board members expressed support for a 2.46% increase at the board's monthly non-voting study session this past Wednesday. Based on that consensus, the board this Wednesday is expected to approve a preliminary budget with a 2.46% increase at the board's monthly voting meeting at East Middle School.

The board has until June 30 to alter that budget. In considering possible change, the school directors said they will take into account how much funding the district receives in the state's 2023-24 budget, which also has a June 30 deadline.

A 2.46% increase would raise taxes by $45.53 for the owner of a home assessed at $100,000, according to the Erie School District. A 2.46% increase would also raise an additional $1,194,894 in revenue, the district said.

Erie schools Superintendent Brian Polito is recommending that the board raise taxes to help the district offset increased costs due to inflation and to ensure that the district has a fund balance for years to come.

The district had risked insolvency for years due to funding woes and increased expenses. The state in 2017 helped the district by increasing the district's annual state funding by $14 million a year, starting in 2018. The state removed the district from financial oversight in September, signaling that the district's financial recovery was complete.

The state-mandated financial improvement plan that the district had to follow while under oversight recommended annual tax increases of 2.46%, mainly to give the district enough revenue to keep up with expenses and maintain a fund balance. The financial improvement plan went into effect in the spring of 2019 and ended in September.

The School Board raised taxes 4.45% for the 2022-23 budget and 3% for the 2021-22 budget. The board did not raise taxes for the 2020-21 budget and raised taxes 2.46% for the 2019-20 budget.

Contact Ed Palattella at epalattella@timesnews.com. Follow him on Twitter @ETNpalattella.

search_result.title: Kansas school choice tax credit program could be expanded with bill
search_result.text:
A Kansas House committee hearing on program that gives tax credits to individuals and companies donating money for private school scholarships quickly devolved into a two-hour long debate on the merits of and successes of Kansas public schools vs. their private counterparts.

The House Committee on K-12 Education Budget on Wednesday held a hearing on HB 2048, a bill that would raise contribution limits under the scholarship program, match tax credits dollar-for-dollar with donation amounts and potentially double the $10 million cap that currently exists for the program.

Supporters of the program have argued that the bill gives families — especially low-income families at schools with poor performance on state assessments — options to choose better performing schools for their children, especially when comparing the program’s $10 million cap against the nearly $6 billion in state expenditures for K-12 education.

But critics and public school advocates dispute the efficacy of the program in accomplishing that goal and have cautioned that the tax credit program is a stepping stone to bigger measures of school choice, which they say would rob public schools of funding and undermine their mission of providing equitable education to all Kansas children.

More:In state of the state address, Laura Kelly warns Republicans away from conservative agenda

How Kansas’ tax credit scholarship program works

First passed into law in 2014, the Tax Credit for Low Income Students Scholarship Program currently allows individuals to receive a tax credit up to 70% of the amount donated to an organization granting scholarships for low-income students to attend private schools.

While the program was originally meant to address only the neediest children in the 100 lowest performing schools in Kansas, recent amendments have expanded the program to include students whose household income is below the limit to receive reduced-price lunch, set at 185% of the federal poverty level. Exact income numbers vary based on household size.

Scholarships had originally been limited to those students if they attended one of the state’s 100 lowest-performing public schools, but the program was opened up to any student in kindergarten through eighth grade in a 2021 revision.

More:Laura Kelly's budget boosts special education funding, state worker pay. Here's what to know.

The program currently limits the maximum credit any taxpayer can receive to $500,000, and the program as a whole is capped at $10 million.

The program has never met that limit, but the Kansas Department of Revenue estimates that the program reached about $5 million in approved credits for the 2022 tax year, and an audit last year determined the program’s recent growth would cause it to reach its limit in the next few years.

Bill could double personal limits, $10M cap on Kansas tax credit scholarship program

Under HB 2048, the tax credit would go up from 70% to a dollar-for-dollar match, still subject to the $500,000 limit for any individual taxpayer.

Legislative staff estimate that increase would cause donations, and subsequent tax credits, to go up an additional $5 million this tax year, with an additional $2 million in growth each subsequent year.

For that reason, the bill also contains a provision that would require the state treasurer to unilaterally increase the tax credit program by 20% any time approved credits exceed 80% of the current maximum, up to $20 million.

More:Kansas bill to criminalize transgender health care for youths. Here's what to know.

The program would become open to high school students for the first time, and new provisions would also allow open the program to any students who are in foster care or whose parents are emergency medical service providers, firefighters, law enforcement or on active duty in the U.S. armed forces,

Several administrators, parents and even students from private schools around Kansas spoke in support of the bill, arguing it allows low-income families access to better opportunities for themselves and their children.

Because of the program, Holy Savior Catholic Academy was able to grow from 146 students in 2018 to 219 students in 2022, said Delia Shropshire, president of the school. Although the school is a part of the Catholic Diocese of Wichita, only 24% of the school’s enrollment is Catholic.

“As the law expanded, so has our enrollment, and as it has progressed, so has the ability for students to choose our school,” she said.

More:Gov. Laura Kelly gives her 2023 State of the State address to the Kansas Legislature

While many may see the tax credit scholarship program as an indictment of public schools as inferior, legislators should instead see the program as being rooted in choice for families, said Terrell Davis, head of school at The Independent School in Wichita. Prior to his leadership at that private preparatory school, Davis was a lobbyist and director of public affairs for Wichita USD 259.

“It’s not about different ideologies,” he said. “It’s not about private or public. This is simply about kids, and what is in the best interest of kids — all kids.”

Public school advocates ask committee members ‘Where’s the beef’ that proves tax credit program success

Meanwhile, representatives from most of the state’s major public education advocacy groups cautioned legislators that the bill, like many other school choice measures, was a misnomer, since parents have always had the right to enroll their children in non-public school options.

Increasing the tax credit limits would not be charity but rather tax avoidance, said Erin Woods, a volunteer for Game On For Kansas Schools, a non-partisan public school advocacy group based out of Johnson County.

More:Kansas high school graduation rates increase. Here's why commissioner says it's not enough

Compared to public schools, which are legally required to accept all students, Woods said private schools are free to turn away families, especially those who do not meet strict religious or ideological criteria or require costly, intensive special education services.

Davis, the private school administrator, had conceded that many private schools are not equipped with the resources to handle such students, but that they work with public schools to handle any needed special education services.

“This bill hands over public tax dollars to schools that do the choosing,” Woods said. “We believe schools receiving public funds should accept and retain all students who apply.”

Mary Sinclair, president of the Kansas State Parent Teacher Association and a Shawnee Mission Board of Education member, said the organization wasn’t necessarily opposed to school choice, but rather hesitated to divert what would have otherwise been state revenue to programs whose successes aren’t clear.

While scholarships for students have to be to private schools either accredited by the Kansas State Board of Education or by another recognized accrediting agency, lawmakers and state agencies have not evaluated the academic success of students or their retention rates once they attend those private schools.

Ann Mah, a Democratic member of the Kansas State Board of Education and former state representative, told the committee that no evidence shows the tax credit program has actually worked to improve student outcomes.

More:Compact could help out-of-state teachers get Kansas licenses. State board not convinced yet

“The original intent was to allow low-income students struggling public schools to go to private schools that perform better and obtain academic achievement,” Mah said. “So where’s the beef? Where are the numbers that show that it worked — that our Kansas scholarship students actually do better academically in private schools?

“Where is the oversight?” Mah continued. “It’s almost like we don’t want to know. If it was a public school program, you would want data six ways from Sunday, but handing out huge tax breaks to an unproven program (is OK).”

Democrats see Kansas tax credit scholarship program as 'shell game' to avoid tax liability

Although Thursday’s hearing was simply to hear testimony and not yet argue the bill, committee members essentially began to debate HB 2048 through sharp questions and criticisms of those presenting testimony.

Republican members pointed out that even if increased to $20 million, the tax credit scholarship program would be a miniscule amount compared to the nearly-$6 billion the state otherwise spends on public schools.

More:Should homeschooled students have a right to play in Kansas high school sports?

They jumped to a Kansas State Department of Education figure that shows on average, public schools spend about $19,000 per student, compared to very rough and varying estimates of about $6,000 at private schools.

That comparison, though, is flawed, since the $19,000 estimate includes all sources of school funding, including federal and local dollars, although state funding is still the biggest chunk. The public schools estimate also includes special education students, who might require tens of thousands of dollars in additional services, skewing any average.

The dollar-for-dollar tax credit would also be unlike any other credit offered in Kansas, argued Rep. Mari-Lynn Poskin, a Leawood Democrat in her second year in the House.

The program, then, could be rife for abuse if a pastor were to direct his or her entire congregation to determine their personal and business tax liabilities and donate the equivalent amounts to scholarship-granting organizations, she said.

“Holy tax scams, that is a masterful shell game,” Poskin said. “For the good of the committee, I just want to reiterate that any religious organization or dark money special interest groups can basically divert their entire group’s entire Kansas tax liability, up to those limits, from our state general funds.”

Republicans vow to make 2023 the year for school choice in Kansas

For years, Republican lawmakers have pushed to greatly expand funding for non-public school options in Kansas, but those efforts had made much smaller progress than the lawmakers had hoped for in recent years.

One priority has been to create an education savings account program that would allow families to use public funding for private school tuition and other education expenses.

Lawmakers in Iowa this month rushed to pass a massive school choice bill that allow any Iowa family access to up to $7,598 in taxpayer funds for education savings account. Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds signed the bill into law Tuesday, and the measure is expected to cost $345 million annually once it is fully phased in over the next four years.

More:Should homeschooled students have a right to play in Kansas high school sports?

Speaking at a National School Choice Rally in the Kansas Statehouse on Wednesday, Sen. Molly Baumgardner, R-Louisburg and chairwoman of the Senate Education Committee, told a group of over 100 private school children that she wants her committee to do the same for Kansas.

“Even though I’m proud to be a Kansas Senator, a Kansas mom and even a Kansas grandma, I wished earlier this week that I was a part of that debate in Iowa, because they had a victory there,” Baumgardner said. “But guess what I want to do with my committee members? We’re going to make sure that you guys go to the schools because it’s your parents’ decision what’s best for you.”

Rep. Kristey Williams, an Augusta Republican and chair of the House K-12 Education Budget Committee, on Wednesday introduced the Sunflower Education Equity Act, which would create a similar education savings account program in Kansas.

She told The Capital-Journal after the hearing that she was confident Kansans support school choice expansion.

“People want choice,” she said. “We live in a very diverse society, and we’re changing the way that we think, the way that we operate and the way we educate. We have technology that’s abound, and I think we should be progressive enough to allow different types of education.”

Although school choice bills have been popular among the Republican majorities in the statehouse, getting those bills passed has been a decidedly uphill battle, especially in rallying enough votes to overturn any vetoes from Gov. Laura Kelly.

More:How can Kansas put students into teacher pipeline? Start with more money, task force says.

Throughout her first term, Kelly has voted down most bills related to school choice. She had signed an expansion of the tax credit program reluctantly in 2021, mostly out of a sense of bipartisanship and a bigger goal of compromise to fully fund Kansas’ public schools.

At the start of her second term, Kelly said she would remain staunchly opposed to any measures that could take away from public school funding.

“I am firmly opposed to school vouchers, always have been,” Kelly told reporters Monday. “I do believe that taxpayer dollars ought to be focused on our public school system. I have always believed that, I continue to believe that."

Rafael Garcia is an education reporter for the Topeka Capital-Journal. He can be reached at rgarcia@cjonline.com or by phone at ‪785-289-5325. Follow him on Twitter at @byRafaelGarcia.

search_result.title: Ed funding: A new formula in Mississippi?
search_result.text:
Bracey Harris

The Clarion-Ledger

In the past four years, Mississippi’s statehouse has seen the passage of major education reforms, including charter schools and initiatives centered on childhood literacy and pre-kindergarten. With the Legislature’s hiring of the New Jersey-based firm EdBuild to propose changes to the oft-debated, twice fully funded Mississippi Adequate Education Program, rewriting the state education formula could be on tap for the approaching legislative session.

In addition to funding, lawmakers also are expected to hone in on school consolidation, the state’s early learning collaborative and school performance.

Student-based emphasis

The structure for the formula is average daily attendance times base student cost plus at-risk component minus local contribution plus 8-percent guarantee. Meant to ensure “adequate current operation funding levels,” the formula has been decried by critics as a behemoth and defended by education advocates and cash-strapped districts who have fought fiercely for funding.

With top Republican leadership, including Gov. Phil Bryant, expressing support for a student-centered funding formula, both sides are wondering if the 2017 session will sound the death knell for the current MAEP structure.

Prep for the polls: See who is running for president and compare where they stand on key issues in our Voter Guide

Senate Education Chairman Gray Tollison, R-Oxford, said lawmakers would “more than likely be considering revisiting the formula.”

EdBuild CEO Rebecca Sibilia has said Mississippi’s funding structure is a hybrid encompassing both student and resource-based funding. Allocations for exceptional-needs students, for example, are based on teacher units, rather than the student’s condition. Under a student-based mechanism, weights for certain needs and characteristics, such as those receiving free and reduced lunch and English-language learners, could be considered add-ons to the base student amount.

“In 20 years, a lot has changed in other states about (school) financing,” Tollison said.

“I think we can be a lot more specific based on a student (as opposed to) a general funding formula across the school districts.”

Tollison suggested that having multipliers added to a base student amount would be better suited to meeting student needs.

House Education Chairman John Moore, R-Brandon, also said he is in favor of adjusting the current structure but doesn't want it rushed.

“Over the last five years, we’ve known there’s been some issues, but I’ve been very hesitant,” Moore explained. “I don’t want to do anything that will be detrimental.”

Before considering changes, Moore said, lawmakers should run “tests” analyzing how funds would be allocated to districts — the agreement between the Legislature and EdBuild references a finance simulator tool.

Some stakeholders are leery that during the evaluation the reality that the formula is routinely underfunded will be lost in the details. According to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, Mississippi is one of 35 states where funding per student in the 2013-14 school year was lower than pre-recession levels.

The next year the Legislature increased the K-12 education budget by $110 million. But several districts took a hit in a budget cut ordered by Bryant in April amid falling revenue.

“We hope to see an increase in funding for school districts, which are struggling in their ninth consecutive year of underfunding and budget cuts,” said Nancy Loome with the Parents’ Campaign, an education advocacy organization.

Early learning collaborative

In May, the National Institute for Early Education Research recognized the state’s early learning collaborative as among the top five in the nation.

And the state Board of Education recently granted partnerships to providers in Canton, Greenwood, Grenada and Starkville and has expanded the slots in the state-funded prekindergarten classes from 1,700 to 2,200.

Funds for the touted successful partnerships, however, reach fewer than 10 percent of the state’s 4-year-olds. The Legislature appropriated $4 million for the collaboratives for the 2016-17 school year. A $6 million funding increase is being sought for the next fiscal year.

About two-thirds of students in Mississippi begin kindergarten without necessary skills, according to the board, citing research that shows children who start school behind “continue to struggle throughout elementary, middle and high school, and have lower graduation rates.”

Since its inception in 2013, appropriation amounts for the program have fallen short of education officials' requests.

The collaborative exists outside the MAEP formula. During a joint education session with EdBuild, Sen. Brice Wiggins, R-Pascagoula, who authored the collaborative, asked whether it would be possible to include the program in a rewritten education formula.

While Sibilia said the inclusion could work, Wiggins told The Clarion-Ledger he’s not in favor of the addition if it alters quality.

He noted that “traditionally districts throughout the state have not focused on early education and the Legislature has not funded early education.”

Data, Wiggins said, has shown the program is of high quality.

“As long as those parameters and the quality remains, I’m all for putting it into the formula. But I don’t want to sacrifice the quality and the framework just to say, ‘we’re putting it in the formula.’ If by putting it in the formula school districts are going to focus on early education, then I’m all for it.”

Accountability

Both Tollison and Moore said they do not expect a major bill tied to accountability to emerge during the session. Moore said he would like the Mississippi Department of Education to provide a debriefing on reform efforts such as The Mississippi Literacy Based Promotion Act.

Known as the "third-grade gate," the law requires third-graders to read at least on basic grade level before being promoted to fourth grade. Statewide, 87 percent of third-graders achieved a passing score on the Third-grade Reading Summative Assessment, which tests students on reading comprehension and proficiency. Last year a bill that would allow MDE to raise the required reading test scores for school year 2018-19 above the basic grade-level died in the Senate education committee. Next year according to a MDE spokesperson, students will have to score above the lowest two achievement levels.

For its part, the state Board of Education has not been shy to express to the Legislature that funds are needed to strengthen improvement efforts.

Nineteen school districts in Mississippi were rated as failing by MDE for the 2016 school year. Districts and schools that make a consecutive F this year could be considered for absorption into the new Mississippi Achievement School District, and the state Board of Education has asked for $250,000 to develop a model for the district.

“The current conservator model does not adequately address improving academic performance,” the board said of its legislative priorities.

An examination of qualifications for becoming a superintendent or school board member is also possible, according to legislative education committee leaders.

School consolidation

In the past session, the Legislature continued its trend of consolidating Mississippi’s 144 school districts, sending Bryant four bills that merged eight of the state’s districts into four.

Tollison told The Clarion-Ledger one of the objectives of administrative consolidation is equity.

“Political lines that were drawn 50 years ago are not conducive to local tax base,” he said. Tollison gave the example of Holmes County, which he said draws a revenue of $100 million compared to nearby Durant's $9.5 million.

Holmes and Durant were two of the districts lawmakers approved for consolidation.

“When that consolidation is complete, the students in Durant will have access that they otherwise wouldn’t have,” Tollison said.

He expects his committee to hone in on districts with similar situations that impact academic performance and areas with “a declining tax base that would be stretched to provide education.”

Precedent suggests new pitches for mergers may not be welcome.

During the summer an advisory council tasked with making recommendations to the Legislature for consolidating three school districts in Chickasaw County failed to reach an agreement.

School choice

Although the landmark Mississippi Charter Schools Act of 2013 permits up to 15 charters to be established per year, fewer than three operate in the state (a high school is slated to open next fall). With both ReImagine Prep and Midtown Public Charter School underperforming on the state's student assessment, the state's authorizer board has made it clear it will not rubber stamp new charters, leading one member to question whether they were deterring prospective operators.

Grant Callen of Empower Mississippi, which advocates school choice, applauded the action and says his organization remains focused on expanding options for students "trapped" in failing schools or districts.

Although an open enrollment bill introduced by Moore last year — a bill that would have allowed students from D and F districts to attend A and B schools — failed to make it out of committee, Bryant's signage of a law permitting students from D and F districts to attend charter schools was seen as a win for the school choice crowd.

This session Callen said he hopes the Legislature will consider increased funding for Educational Scholarship Accounts. The program provides awards of up to $6,637 to parents of exceptional needs children to help defray the costs of alternatives to public school.

The accounts have seen some push-back with stakeholders pointing out the law does not help strengthen resources in public schools.

Loome is among those who have expressed concerns that the program fails to provide a long-term solution, noting private schools have the option of selecting who is admitted.

Although funding for ESA has remained level ($3 million in Fiscal Year 2017), the demand for scholarships outweighs resources. In his executive budget recommendation, Bryant noted 425 students are enrolled in the program while 130 remain on the waiting list. The law allows for up to 1,500 spots for the 2017-18 school year.

Contact Bracey Harris at bharris2@gannett.com or 601-961-7248. Follow her on Twitter.

search_result.title: KERA at 30: How did the Kentucky Education Reform Act hold up?
search_result.text:
Just over three decades ago, a judge issued Kentucky a stern message: Your education system is broken. Fix it.

Within a year, Kentucky lawmakers responded with a watershed piece of legislation: The Kentucky Education Reform Act.

Signed on April 11, 1990 — 30 years ago today — the bill, known as KERA, overhauled how the Bluegrass State funded schools and instituted measures to prevent political corruption.

Schools would also be judged on the performance of all students, being held to what some consider the nation's first school accountability model.

"You see Kentucky's 1990 story as one of success, where we increase student outcomes across the board for all students," said Brigitte Blom Ramsey, who runs Prichard Committee, a nonpartisan education advocacy group. "We started climbing the rankings in (national tests). And we were, I think, in the top five in the nation making improvement."

But myriad changes and challenges over the three decades that followed eroded Kentucky's signature education legislation, leaving the state's school system at a tipping point.

The legislation's signature tenets — equitable funding, a school accountability system, school-based councils, depoliticized overseers — are either underfunded, routinely tweaked or otherwise threatened.

And as the coronavirus weighs upon Kentucky households and the economy, it is unclear how much change Kentucky can afford in the coming years.

After some initial gains from KERA, Kentucky has plateaued.

"It really worked," said Cindy Heine, a retired associate director of the Prichard Committee. "It has worked. It is no longer working."

Rich district, poor district

In the mid-1980s, inequities in Kentucky's education system were clear.

Rural school districts often had less money than their wealthier peers, meaning fewer resources and opportunities for their students.

Kentucky clung to the bottom rung of most national rankings: last in high school graduations, one of the highest poverty rates, third from last in education funding.

A Lexington Herald Leader article from the time said Kentucky was "cheating our children."

So, a group of dozens of districts, school boards and public school students, mainly from rural, cash-strapped districts, sued, arguing Kentucky's system was a failure.

The case ended up in front of the state Supreme Court, which agreed Kentucky's K-12 school system was inequitable and inadequate. The 1989 Rose v. Council for Better Education decision threw out existing laws and sparked an overhaul.

“The children of the poor and the children of the rich, the children who live in the poor districts and the children who live in the rich districts must be given the same opportunity and access to an adequate education," the ruling said.

Lawmakers, tasked with building a new education system, responded a year later with KERA.

The landmark legislation created a school accountability system, where educators would be held accountable for the performance of their students. While common now, Heine believes Kentucky's model was one of the first accountability systems in the country.

KERA required state lawmakers to fund schools differently. The SEEK — Support Education Excellence in Kentucky — model guaranteed districts a minimum amount of money for each student. It combined local and state dollars, with poorer districts getting more from the state and paying less in taxes locally.

And it tried to take the politics out of education by changing how the state education chief was selected, tweaking local hiring practices and introducing a council at each school to include parent and teacher input.

​​​"Without a doubt, KERA worked," Blom Ramsey, the Prichard leader and a former state education board member, said.

'With every dime that we have'

Despite its successes, some of KERA's elements disintegrated quickly.

A primary program that kept kids in a gradeless classroom until they were ready for the fourth grade fell by the wayside as educators and parents grew frustrated with the out-of-the-box approach. "Performance events" in which students solved problems in small groups also dissipated.

Other aspects eroded over time.

Most troubling for some districts, the funding gap KERA sought to fix is nearing what it was before the 1990 legislation. This comes after years of flat or under-funding from the state, or local school boards not raising taxes.

“(SEEK) was meant as an equalizer," Traysea Moresea, the superintendent of Greenup County Schools, said. "And it has lost that for rural schools.”

Powell County rests on the line between Central and Eastern Kentucky. Its population is dwindling, so it is losing per student funding while its fixed costs are not dropping.

Property values are growing thanks to the local tourism industry, meaning its local tax base is growing. But in the SEEK formula, that means they get less money from the state.

"We're taking a double whammy," said Anthony Orr, the Powell County superintendent.

More:How is JCPS handling grades during distance learning? Here's what to know

Like many rural Kentucky districts, transportation is tricky. "Really challenging roadways," prone to flooding, mixed with mountains lead to higher maintenance costs, Orr said.

With kids scattered throughout the county, some bus routes stretch over an hour. Kentucky only partially funds school transportation — around 60% — which disproportionately hurts smaller districts, which don't have the local funds to make up the difference but desperately need more buses and maintenance.

“If they would just fund transportation 100%, we could offer so much more to our students," Moresea said. "And that would be an equalizer for us.”

With that money, Moresea would be able to get more buses and shorten trips.

“We are reallocating to the best of our possibilities," Moresea said. They're working to stay competitive with neighboring districts and private schools, "but we're doing it with every dime we have."

Often, public districts need to go beyond the classroom to help with kids' basic needs, such as food and mental health services.

And in an area hit by the opioid epidemic, kids are coming to them with more need than ever before, Moresea said.

“We are the first and sometimes only caretakers for children," Moresea said.

Even the district's youngest learners face lengthy bus rides, sometimes ending with a bus driver needing to wake them up when they get home. And sometimes that home doesn't have water, she said.

“We're their only saving grace," Moresea said of some of her students.

More funding would help close gaps in achievement, too, the district leaders say.

There's "no question" that state-funded preschool and full-day kindergarten would help Powell County's youngest learners, Orr said. It would level the playing field for the impoverished student body, he said.

A new normal:How JCPS students, teachers and parents grappled with distance learning

And it would free up local money to cover instructional coaches to help his educators improve their teaching skills, he said, helping older students.

Or freed-up money could go to facilities. Aging HVAC systems are a "drain" on Powell County's maintenance budget.

“You can’t expect kids to learn if they’re sitting in coats, shivering," Orr said.

Ultimately, Kentucky needs new revenue, and that needs to come from the state level, Orr said. Several school boards have already taxed out.

“It’s tight all the way around," Orr said.

"Listen with an open mind to what educators are asking for," Moresea said. Teachers are not asking to be the richest people, but for "resources to help kids."

A gradual erosion

How Kentucky grades its students' performance and identifies struggling schools has seen multiple iterations since the accountability model's inception.

Kentucky used different accountability models over the years: CATS, Unbridled Learning, K-PREP. Tweaks are made so often that educators joke that the only certain thing is that their target will move.

Before starting as superintendent last year, Moresea led Greenup County's assessment and curriculum team.

To have a true measure of results, Kentucky needs a consistent measurement, Moresea said. Putting more focus into teaching, rather than tests, "would go a long way."

“I've really quit talking about aiming for K-PREP scores," Orr, in Powell County, said. He's focusing on simply teaching kids.

It is "very, very difficult" to get an accountability system, Heine said. Should it be broad or focus in on reading and math?

Initially, KERA's accountability focus was broad. Over time, through tweaks and changes, it has become narrow. Students are still tested in social studies and science, but the focus often lands on reading and math.

A bill again tweaking how Kentucky grades and identifies schools for support cleared multiple hurdles in the state legislature before halting when lawmakers cut days out of the session.

Local school boards were notoriously corrupt around the time of KERA, sparking the creation of school-level councils that would control how individual schools spent their money and what curriculum they used.

Those councils are "largely intact," Blom Ramsey said. But legislation pops up annually to tinker with the groups, often asking to take away their power to hire a school's principal or to change the makeup of the group.

Like the school accountability bill, a bill moving the councils' hiring authority is withering because of a shortened legislative session.

State-level overseers are on shaky ground, too.

To reduce politics in education, KERA moved away from electing an education chief. Instead, a governor-appointed board would hire the commissioner. The board's terms would be staggered, so a governor would have a board fully appointed by themselves only toward the end of their term.

More:What JCPS parents need to know about special education during coronavirus closures

That has been threatened in recent years, with the last two commissioners resigning under pressure days after a new education board has been appointed.

Hours after former Gov. Matt Bevin appointed new people to the board to fill expired terms, the now fully Bevin-appointed board called for a special meeting to discuss their sole employee: The commissioner.

A day later, former commissioner Stephen Pruitt resigned under fire.

Over a year later, specifically citing ideological differences with Bevin's appointees, Gov. Andy Beshear abolished and recreated the education board, filling it with his own picks. The new members soon after accepted former commissioner Wayne Lewis' resignation.

The board Beshear ousted quickly sued, arguing in part that KERA intended for the board to be nonpartisan and free from politics.

Legislation preventing similar reorganizations and requiring a politically diverse board is all but dead as lawmakers head into their last week of the session.

But legislators need to confirm Beshear's newest board members — which the Republican-led Senate doesn't seem poised to do because the board is all Democrats — before adjourning. If they don't, Beshear will need to appoint a new board during lengthy school closures caused by a pandemic.

Amid a worsening coronavirus outbreak, shuttered schools and fears of a recession, it is unclear what Kentucky will face next and how it would fund it.

"In past economic recessions, Kentuckians with the least education were the ones most negatively impacted, and as a result, our economic growth has lagged the nation," Blom Ramsey said in a recent press release.

But one thing is clear: If Kentucky doesn't change its approach to education, it may slide further, Blom Ramsey said.

"Nobody is standing still," Blom Ramsey said. "We've been standing still for a while, not making additional improvements. And all the while, other states are starting to pass us by. And we're falling behind.

"There should be a great sense of urgency to continue to improve if Kentucky wants to maintain its place as a national leader in education and one that has realized success even as a very poor state."

search_result.title: An Iowa school district thinks 4-day weeks may ease staffing concerns
search_result.text:
The Cardinal Community School District is poised to join a short list of Iowa districts with four-day school weeks, gambling that the promise of three-day weekends will be attractive to teachers while still allowing students to get their required instruction time.

The school board, after considering the option for years, is set to vote on the proposal Monday. If the measure passes, with the exception of a few weeks early in the school year, the district will move to a Tuesday-Friday class schedule.

"I believe that we will have a competitive advantage by recruiting and retaining staff that value time over money and lifestyle," said Joel Pedersen, superintendent of the district of nearly 1,000 students that spans the southeast Iowa counties of Davis, Jefferson, Van Buren and Wapello.

The Cardinal district would join a few other rural school districts in Iowa that have moved to four-day weeks, including WACO in Wayland, Mormon Trail in Humeston and Moulton-Udell. All have cited a desire to attract students and teachers.

According to Tim Bartels, principal of WACO Junior and Senior High School, his district's move to Monday-Thursday school weeks in 2013 has helped him recruit teachers.

"While bigger schools might be able to pay more, time is a non-renewable resource. And I tell every single person we interview, 'I cannot give you a what they give you in pay, but I can give you something they can't.' And that's time," he said. "Time with family. Time with friends. Time off to go do stuff. Throughout COVID, we learned that (time) was very valuable."

More in education:Kim Reynolds reworked her private school scholarship bill to win rural lawmakers. Will it be enough?

Within the past four years, Bartels said he has been contacted by approximately 20 school districts curious about the logistics and benefits of four-day school weeks, including the Cardinal Community School District.

Cardinal's proposed changes would include a few five-day school weeks on the 2022-2023 calendar through October. Then, a combination of professional development days, parent-teacher conferences, holiday and vacation days, combined with designated "no-school" days on the schedule, would shorten the school weeks for the rest of the academic year.

The proposal would also extend school days by 20-25 minutes, with the classes at the elementary school starting at 8 a.m. and ending at 3:40 p.m.. The middle and high school would begin classes at 8 a.m. and dismiss students at 3:47 p.m.

Under state law, Iowa school districts and accredited nonpublic schools are required to provide either 180 days or 1,080 hours of instruction to students. The proposed 2022-2023 schedule for Cardinal would consist of only 150 school days, but provide a total of 1,095 hours of learning.

The district believes switching to a four-day week will have multiple benefits, including helping retain staff, attracting teachers to the district, allowing staff more time to prepare for classes and work on professional development, boosting teacher and student morale, and a reduction of student and staff absences.

Additional benefits for the district could include cost savings on fuel and substitute teachers.

To ensure that hourly employees will not see a reduction in wages, Pedersen said the district will adjust its hourly rates to make up for the difference.

The plan appears to have strong support among district staff, with 95% in favor of the proposed schedule in a recent survey, according to Pedersen.

More in education:Kim Reynolds wanted more charter schools in Iowa. But only two groups have applied to open them.

Day care, school lunches are concerns about a shorter school week

The Cardinal Community School District's proposal carries some uncertainties and concerns.

The district's preschool program already operates on a Tuesday-Friday schedule. It is unclear whether the district will provide day-care services on Mondays, if the four-day schedule is adopted. Pedersen said the district intends to survey parents before reaching a decision on making day care available on Mondays.

Providing breakfast and lunch to students during Mondays with no class is another concern. According to data from the Iowa Department of Education, in 2021, 55% of students in the Cardinal district qualified for free or reduced lunch.

Pedersen said the district is working with local partners to open food pantries in all of its schools to help with those experiencing food insecurities.

"This is a community need, not just a school need," he said.

Another area of concern is whether more students will engage in criminal activity as a result of time away from school and lack of parental supervision on Mondays. Pedersen does not believe this will be a significant issue.

"We have two Mondays off already, and we have not seen an uptick in this area," he said.

More in education:Iowa Republicans boost school funding by 2.5%, Democrats say it isn't enough

Four-day school weeks growing in popularity in other states, like Colorado

Four-day school weeks are hardly a novel concept.

A recent Brookings Institute report notes that, during the springtime prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, 662 school districts were on four-day school weeks across 24 states, an increase of more than 600% since 1999.

Since the pandemic, more than 1,600 school districts are estimated to have switched to four-day weeks.

Colorado leads the way, with 114 of the state's 178 school districts, or 64%, on four-day schedules.

A June overview on schools utilizing four-day weeks published by the Colorado Department of Education said those districts "tend to be rural and sparsely populated," requiring some students to travel longer distances to get to class or athletic events.

Four-day weeks are also present in an estimated 40% of school districts in New Mexico and Oregon.

Bartels said the WACO district's move to a four-day week was initiated by a group of teachers brainstorming ways to meet the learning needs of students.

Those teachers began researching classroom instruction, school-day structures and other learning environments, concluding that a better path forward should include class periods where teachers could use every single instructional minute.

Bartels said this calculation and move to four-day week led to the elimination of study halls, plus slightly longer school days that include seven class periods.

Longer class times have allowed teachers to squeeze in more lectures and practice time with students, Bartels said, with the result of a decrease in homework for many students.

"We didn't need the study halls, because with a study hall, a student sits there by themselves and they don't have a teacher," Bartels said. "I don't send a kid to basketball practice without a coach. So we don't send a kid off with homework without them knowing how to do that schoolwork independently, or, if they don't, that teacher is in the room with them the whole time."

More in education:These two Iowa educators just earned a national award for teaching science and math

Bartels added that four-day weeks have had no apparent impact on student test scores or the district's culture.

Bartels did concede that on the few Fridays during the beginning of the school year when classes are being held and students have to show up "it is like pulling them in on a Saturday."

But Bartels said attendance numbers have been generally good and students seem willing to put in the hard work necessary to earn an extra day off.

"They know that they don't have to come in on Fridays, and that's been a big boost," he said.

'Teacher is biggest predictor of student success': Why superintendent thinks he can gain a competitive edge

For Pedersen, if a four-day school week can help the district keep and attract teaching staff, that sense of consistency and collaboration between teachers and students is the most attractive tradeoff of the proposal, regardless of studies that warn of the possible downsides of lost instructional time.

"I have seen studies that show many different results for the four-day week," he said. "I would counter that the research is clear that the teacher is the biggest predictor of student success over any school factor."

Advocating for the schedule change, the district's website asserts that lower teacher retention percentages "have been shown to greatly impact the scholastic performance of students" and that "studies have shown that students who are subject to higher teacher turnover suffer in terms of achievement gains."

"We certainly will watch our test scores, but to me this is bigger than standardized test scores," Pedersen said. "I want a quality teacher in front of every student consistently in grades Pre-K through 12. If we can achieve that, I'm convinced that the scores will be fine."

More in education:Iowa won't require schools to put live cameras in classrooms after Republican bill dies

The Cardinal Community School District is currently seeking to fill five positions, including a principal opening at the high school.

Pedersen said the district has dealt with increasing hiring challenges within the past five years, particularly in areas like science, math, special education and foreign languages.

"Even elementary positions that we had 100 applicants 10 years ago, now will have under 10 applicants," Pedersen said.

Pedersen said the district's salary schedule is improving but he realizes he is unable to compete with larger schools or against the amenities bigger cities can provide.

"We have to think differently, and there has been possible applicants inquiring about the four-day schedule," he said.

'Many are just quitting': Teacher shortage is problem across Iowa

Big or small, districts across the state have struggled this academic year with staffing shortages.

According to the Iowa Department of Education website Teach Iowa, there are currently more than 4,500 openings at schools across the state.

Pedersen said the COVID-19 pandemic has taken an additional toll.

"The pandemic has been so stressful for teachers," he said. "The concern over safety and teachers trying to teach online and in-person has worn them out. Many are retiring early and many are just quitting."

The difficulty finding teachers is compounded by the fact that fewer college students are choosing that profession.

During the 2018-2019 academic year, data from the Department of Education shows a 20% drop in the number of people going to college in Iowa to study education during the previous decade, plus a 22% drop in the number of Iowa students completing those degrees.

"We are experiencing an exponential problem, to use a math term," Pedersen said. "This is going to take bold initiatives from our legislators to stop."

More in education:Norwalk district taps high school students to help fill paraeducator staffing shortage

Pedersen suggested that state lawmakers are also contributing to the teacher shortage, by not properly funding public schools.

"While we appreciate 2.5% state supplemental aid, inflation is at 7% and we will settle at close to 3% due to collective bargaining laws," Pedersen said. "The state has the largest surpluses ever, we hoped this would be a year to receive at least 4%. A decade of funding below 4% except for one year compounds the problems with paying teachers more.

"When many employers are paying more than a starting teacher salary in many schools, that is going to cause challenges for hiring the best and the brightest and keeping them in education."

Still, Pedersen said he is motivated by the challenge of finding educators willing to teach in his smaller, more rural district.

"The data is clear that rural schools receive less applicants than our urban counterparts," Pedersen said.

"I don’t begrudge any of my urban colleagues for this current situation. We can either mindlessly complain or look for solutions by innovating. As the leader of Cardinal CSD, I choose to be solution-oriented."

search_result.title: School supporters brainstorm ways to boost education in Northampton
search_result.text:
More than 70 Northampton County leaders who want to see the county's public schools succeed came together Tuesday at the Northampton County Education Foundation's first annual State of the Schools community forum.

The group included businesspeople, clergy, elected officials, parents, media representatives and school employees, among others.

As the morning progressed, the Northampton High School gymnasium wall filled rapidly with colorful stickers enumerating results of eight simultaneous roundtable discussions about the schools' successes and challenges, as well as initiatives the groups thought should be considered.

Wayne Bell and Jeff Holland facilitated the session.

Results are being compiled and a report will be sent to all participants.

"This isn't a one and done," said Holland, executive director of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge-Tunnel.

"Today is a positive day," he said.

The day started with a continental breakfast served by students in the high school's hospitality and tourism program and musical selections performed by the high school chorus. That was followed by a speech by School Superintendent Eddie Lawrence, who listed dozens of achievements accomplished by students and staff at the county's two elementary schools, one middle school and one high school.

Lawrence spoke at length about each school's accomplishments, including academic improvements, athletic achievements and state and regional awards won by students and staff.

He noted that Occohannock Elementary School, after remaining for a decade in some kind of school improvement plan, is now fully accredited.

One challenge the eight roundtable groups agreed is important to address is finding better ways to get the word out to the public about those accomplishments.

Another is funding — with less money coming from the state due to a decline in student population along with what some say is a flawed state funding formula.

Lawrence acknowledged the state of the schools "is a little bit of a mixed bag of results," adding, "but, of course, any organization is."

The district over the past 14 years lost about 500 students, resulting in an increasing challenge for schools to continue to offer a full spectrum of educational programs.

"When your population shrinks, your state assistance and your funding shrinks," Lawrence said.

RELATED: Hope finally fulfilled: Eastern Shore Community College marks construction project

However, the district last year had an unexpected boost in numbers, going from 1,505 to 1,570 students.

"While that is very encouraging and promising, I'm not yet ready to call that a trend," Lawrence said.

Northampton County is among the poorest localities in Virginia, but it has relatively high land values, making for another major challenge to the school district — a state funding formula some say leaves the county bearing an unfair burden.

The local composite index — a measurement of the locality's ability to pay — for Northampton is 0.49. That means for every dollar the state contributes for education, the county is expected to contribute nearly the same amount.

"It has us with a greater ability to pay than Virginia Beach, Chesapeake, Newport News and Accomack County," Lawrence said.

Still, Northampton County actually pays more than the state requires. The school board budget this year totals $20.6 million, and the county is footing $8.6 million of that — about $2 million more than the state requires.

"So we have, I think, a very supportive Board of Supervisors," Lawrence said.

Northampton County Board of Supervisors Chairman Spencer Murray during the roundtable discussion said it is the board's job "to just give every penny we can to the elected school board and to the administration to run the program," adding that bringing economic development into the county is key.

"We fuel the whole economy with jobs, and the more money that we have coming into our communities, the more money that we'll be able to give to schools," Murray said.

"Funding runs across all these issues we're talking about," he said.

Another major challenge participants identified was teacher recruitment and retention.

Lawrence noted teacher salary in the county is the lowest in the region, making it difficult to attract and retain teachers.

READ MORE: Va. Shore's past and present on display at exhibit

Nevertheless, the district wants to find ways to increase its academic and career and technical programs, including in the areas of cybersecurity and agriculture, he said.

Lawrence and roundtable participants agreed that partnerships, in particular with Eastern Shore Community College, are key to doing more with the available resources.

Dual enrollment courses and the possibility of a welding program to be offered in partnership with the college will enhance the school district's offerings, he said.

"We hope to expand our partnership in the upcoming years," Lawrence said.

"We have lots of things we need to work on ... I'm really excited about the direction that Northampton County schools are going in, but we do have lots of obstacles to overcome," he said.

The foundation's mission is to engage the community and mobilize resources to promote student performance and excellence in teaching in Northampton County Public Schools.

In addition to organizing Tuesday's forum, the foundation last year raised more than $11,500 for the schools. The money went toward classroom grants, a teacher recognition banquet, $25 gift cards given to new teachers and $1,500 in student scholarships.

Grants from the foundation supported school activities ranging from the high school play to participation in a robotics competition; a student athlete tutoring program; pre-K summer camps to improve school readiness at Occohannock Elementary School and Kiptopeke Elementary School; and the Reflections writing and art contest at the middle and high schools, among other initiatives.

search_result.title: School levy is necessary for Columbus students – if voters can wrap ...
search_result.text:
Dispatch Editorial Board

Columbus Dispatch

It has been long believed Columbus Board of Education was on a different page than many in the community.

In the past months — way before the district's 7.7-mill permanent levy was placed on the Nov. 7 ballot — it has become apparent the district and the people are not reading the same book.

There may never be a good time to ask voters for nearly $100 million more annually in property taxes. But the school board's strained relationship with the community, the district's poor academic performance and Columbus' high cost of living make this a decidedly a bad one.

If the school levy is approved, property owners will shell out about $180 more per $100,000 of property valuation when the taxes are first collected in 2024.

Many residents — seniors in particular — are already pinned against the wall by economic forces beyond their control as taxes and home values increase in a city battling an affordable housing crisis.

But if the levy is rejected, Columbus' kids — many of whom are still struggling with the dire social, emotional and intellectual impacts of the pandemic — will continue to pay a heavy price.

More:Culture-war issues take center stage in many central Ohio school board races

It's a complex predicament.

With Issue 11, Columbus voters are being asked to wager if school officials are playing typical gloom-and-doom politics to get what they want against potentially rejecting the levy, thusly exacerbating the real challenges Columbus City Schools children face.

The district's leaders — current and former — have made this bed, but nobody wants to see our kids lay in it.

School board acknowledges missteps

As inadvertently as it may have been, the board — which will oversee a $1.6 billion budget in 2024 — has given voters reason to be skeptical of its word.

President Jennifer Adair acknowledges mistakes were made in relaying information to the community about the district's needs and the levy.

"That's on us. That's on the board. That's on me," she said. "As the president, I accept responsibility and accountability for that. The only way forward is to say, 'let's all go forward'."

Adair said the board wants the public's feedback and would work to repair relationships that began to deteriorate decades before she and the current board took office beginning in 2019.

The vote "yes" school levy campaign got a slow start and information about why it is needed has not been conveyed well beyond meetings and the district's website, Adair said.

Garnering support for the levy has been challenging.

Why has the Columbus school levy been a hard sell?

The high cost of the levy as property values increase to record levels is among the complaints.

"You will not balance the CCS budget on the backs of this community, especially on senior citizens," Columbus NAACP President Nana Watson, a vocal opponent of the school levy, recently told a Dispatch reporter.

The Franklin County Auditor's Office has for months told residents the county's average property values would increase by 41%. Property taxes won't increase that much from the reappraisal, but the levy complicates legitimate cost concerns.

Residents are navigating the reappraisals and potential impact on their bottom lines. Renters worry landlords will ask for more money if the levy passes.

Add to that the fact that many voters do not believe they are getting a good return on their financial investment and the reasons for the disconnect are clear.

More:Shame on Columbus school board for asking for more money, showing faces| Letters

More:School reports cards were released by the state Thursday. Columbus City Schools got worse.

The Ohio Department of Education's annual report cards released in September revealed that Columbus schools showed no improvement in some categories and declined in others.

School board transparency and its strained relationship with stakeholders have been raised multiple times by those who have rejected the levy or otherwise refused to endorse it.

Last month, a coalition of Black religious leaders that includes The Baptist Ministerial Alliance of Columbus and Vicinity, The Baptist Pastor's Conference of Columbus and Vicinity and the Interdenominational Ministerial Alliance of Columbus and Vicinity, announced that it would not support the levy.

The 500-member Columbus Chapter of the NAACP is actively campaigning against the levy, positioning vote "no" signs throughout the community.

Equity Now Coalition board members recently declined to endorse the levy. Known as the ENC, the group's membership includes 75 Black leaders. The board recommendation included that the levy be taken off of the ballot, there be public review of efforts to reduce costs, and that Adair be replaced with a new school board president.

It is telling and nearly unheard of that a majority Black urban school district would receive public levy push back from so many Black-lead organizations.

Columbus shouldn't be having this fight

The Ohio Supreme Court ruled the state's method of funding schools unconstitutional more than 26 years ago.

It is dead wrong, unsustainable and illogical that so much of the burden for paying for schools is still being placed on the backs of taxpayers, seniors in particular.

Columbus' new Superintendent Angela Chapman, who helps her father navigate his finances, agreed with that premise at least in part.

"It is incumbent upon us as citizens — taxpayers in the city — to put pressure on our legislators to work on a legislative fix," she told members of our editorial board during a meeting that also included Adair, Columbus Education Association President John Coneglio and Jennifer Vanover, the district's interim treasurer.

District leaders say the financial challenges did not hit them by surprise, and there were efforts to right the district's ship long before the levy was placed on the ballot.

Vanover told our board that about $16 million in non-personnel related spending were cut from the budget in January. The district had intended to cut $30 million.

What's at stake

School heating and cooling issues and other unacceptable issues were thrust into the limelight as a result of attention drawn to the district by the teachers' union 2022 strike.

Mice droppings, roaches, leaks, and other substandard conditions were found by Columbus Public Health last year, according to records obtained by the Dispatch.

Some progress has been made.

All but one school now has air conditioning. Mifflin Middle School's HVAC system is still under construction and set to be complete by next summer.

If the 7.7-mill levy is approved, $38.6 million would be used for operations and $60.5 million would be used to maintain the district's 113 school buildings.

If the levy fails, officials warn schools, fields and other facilities will continue to deteriorate, implanting the message in students that they deserve to learn in inadequate environments.

If the levy fails, the district would stop a plan to expand pre-K. Conflict training and other programs for the most vulnerable students will be cut. The district will not be able to repair or replace critical equipment such as student computers and employees will lose their jobs.

This includes the nearly 650 counselors, interpreters, social workers, substitute teachers, custodians, security guards and other employees hired with Elementary and Secondary School Emergency Relief funds the district received from the federal government in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Even if the levy is approved, 353 of those positions will end when the last of the $287.6 million ESSER fund — about $121 million — is used up by September 2024.

There is little doubt that students — particularly those who fell behind during the pandemic — will suffer if counselors are cut from schools.

To drive this point home, Chapman relayed the story of a distraught student who tried to throw himself off a second-story balcony.

"The social, emotional supports to me are non-negotiable. Think about the needs of our students," she said. "Our students are experiencing a tremendous amount of trauma in the community."

The Columbus way

The pandemic caused major setbacks for Columbus City Schools, but Chapman and her team are on the ground working to turn things around. They deserve a chance.

Voters will ultimately decide if Chapman's strategy is worth more of their investment or if the school board must build community trust and return to the drawing board to come up with a solution that is more palatable to voters.

Regardless of Issue 11's outcome, there's an immediate need for more community involvement in Columbus City Schools.

State lawmakers should work to reduce the tax burden on property owners, but there are things that can be done at the community level to improve Columbus City Schools.

School officials hope to establish a foundation that can help raise funds to mitigate the impact on school districts residents.

The business community must more deeply embrace the Columbus Way — a concept of public-private partnerships — when it comes to Columbus City Schools.

Equally as important, the public should hold the school board to Adair's promise to build relationships with partners from social services, business, community and governmental agencies — the ENC, NAACP and religious organizations included.

The hurdles are high, but it is worth the fight.

The future of Columbus depends on it.

This piece was written by the Dispatch Opinion Editor Amelia Robinson on behalf of The Dispatch Editorial Board. Editorials are our board's fact-based assessment of issues of importance to the communities we serve. These are not the opinions of our reporting staff members, who strive for neutrality in their reporting.
